results.description:
Note: We have a change of venue for tonight. We are meeting at 90 Broadway (formerly 4 Cambridge Center). This building is attached to Meadhall.

About the speaker: 

Isaac is a software developer recently relocated to the Boston area from Israel. Starting as a systems programmer in the army, he has since worked as a backend software developer in various fields such as economics, security and travel. Currently he is a senior software developer for the Here mapping division of Nokia, using Python, Django and sometimes even Scala.

About the talk:

Django as a backend for data mining - Isaac will be giving a talk on using Django as a backend for performing data mining from social media. This will be a general introduction to web APIs and entity resolution with Django.  He'll also be talking about best practices for using different social media APIs (Wikipedia, Instagram, foursquare, etc.) and how to build an architecture around it with Django as a backend.

About the sponsor and post-talk drinks:

We will be having drinks at a local bar after the talk. Klaviyo is sponsoring the drinks and also looking to hire Django developers. More info coming soon!

Contact Andrew for more info about Klaviyo positions.
results.name: Isaac Vidas: Django as a Backend for Data Mining

results.description:
Itadaki downstairs bar (Boston, Newbury St. between Gloucester and Fairfield) 7 pm to 10 pm

Join me at this izakaya style venue for a pleasant evening of drinks, food and chats. Whether you're learning Japanese or English, buy a drink, join the table, and practice your new language in a friendly and relaxed environment. If you're a beginner or just interested in culture, you'll fit in fine! Don't miss out on this opportunity to learn and practice over a few drinks. Can't make it on time? Need to leave early? Not a problem. Just stop by if you can!

If you are >21 and plan to drink, please bring a MA state issued ID or passport. Other state IDs may not be accepted. Please order at the bar and take care of your own tab.

Transportation: I highly recommend using public transportation. Not only is driving while intoxicated dangerous, but there may not be any parking available in the area. A lot of the parking on Newbury St  is Residential Only in the evenings, and many of the signs indicating this are very well hidden. If you insist on parking in the area, be aware that meter maids love handing out parking tickets around here. Best methods for public transportation are the green line subway or bus #1 to the Hynes stop.

I have made an arrangements with the Itadaki staff for a simpler ordering method. Last time was very chaotic and stressful for the bartender, so lets do our best to not confuse the bartender. :)

Ordering at Itadaki

1) Order your first drink at the bar. If it's alcoholic, your ID will be checked at this time. You will also be  given a guest number to use the rest of the night.

2) If you're at a table, the bartender will try to make several rounds throughout the night to take additional orders. Keep using your guest number and please feel free to order more food and drinks.

3) Keep in mind we're a pretty large group so don't be offended or annoyed with the bartender if he doesn't get to you right away. If you have an urgent order, go request it at the bar.

4) Please take care of your tab and don't forget to tip*. The management and staff are doing a lot to make this all possible.

*Note: If the group is large, an 18% tip may already be included.

See you there!
~Lindsay

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

Please note there is no glassware of any kind allowed in the pool area.  If you have something that is in a glass container you will need to keep that in the clubhouse.

There is a $3.00 guest fee that you will need to give to the pool monitor when you arrive.

When you arrive in the complex just go straight and you will see the clubhouse and pool on your left and on your right there is parking and a small parking lot and walk up the walkway to the left of the clubhouse.

Call me on my cell when you arrive so I can let you in[masked]-0136.

results.description:
Sign-up for the Webinar at: https://www.innerengineering.com/online/free-meditation-webinars-2?signinsrc=Meetup-NewEngland

***REGISTRATION closes 45 minutes prior to the webcast.***  Please make sure you sign-up on our website at least 45 mins prior to the webcast to receive your live log-in link via email. 

(Technical Support:[masked]) 


Isha Kriya Guided Meditation-

A lot of people find it really difficult to calm the mind and settle the body for meditation when they first try it. Too many people get frustrated and give up on meditation before they can experience its many benefits.

These 1-hour guided sessions offer a simple, but powerful kriya practice that aligns your mind, body, and inner-energies to easily and naturally become meditative. Once meditative, your experience of the life within you and the world around you becomes much deeper and richer. Daily activity becomes effortless and joyful. 

You can easily learn this 12-to-18 minute Isha Kriya process in one session and practice on your own, or return to class to ask questions and deepen the experience with the group. Benefits of regular practice include improving health, energy and vitality; enhancing mental focus, memory and clarity; reducing stress and establishing a deep sense of peace and inner balance.

Isha Kriya is a gentle, seated practice, which can be practiced in a chair. No previous meditation experience is necessary.

The Isha Kriya process was developed by realized yogi, Sadhguru Vasudev. Sadhguru is renowned for his powerful yoga and meditation programs, as well as thriving humanitarian initiatives. He has been hosted to speak and offer meditations at numerous global leadership forums, businesses and universities, including the United Nations, the World Economic Forum, the British House of Lords, TED, MIT, and the World Peace Congress.

This free session will be facilitated by a trained Isha Kriya instructor. Contact: [masked],[masked] for more information about Isha USA or this session.

For more on Sadhguru and Isha, visit IshaUSA.org/blog
results.name: Isha Kriya Guided Meditation--FREE Class (Online Webinar)

results.description:
So there's a new documentary being released about Conrad Anker, Jimmy Chin, Renan Ozturk attempting to climb Mt Meru in the Indian Himalayas, which looks to be a cut above your typical climbing film.

There's a special screening on opening night with a post-film Q&A with Renan Ozturk (spoiler alert, he survives), and I would also suggest a post-film-post-Q&A drink at CBC just round the corner.

Anyway, I'm not organising more than that, because, well, I'm lazy. But tickets are eleven dollars and can be had here:
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/meru-the-north-face-speaker-series-boston-2015-tickets-17978208305

==========


Film details from kendall square cinema:
http://www.landmarktheatres.com/boston/kendall-square-cinema/film-info/meru

In the high-stakes pursuit of big-wall climbing, the Shark's Fin on Mount Meru may be the ultimate prize. Sitting 21,000 feet above the sacred Ganges River in Northern India, the mountain’s perversely stacked obstacles make it both a nightmare and an irresistible calling for some of the world's toughest climbers. In October 2008, renowned alpinists Conrad Anker, Jimmy Chin and Renan Ozturk arrived in India to tackle Meru. Their planned seven-day trip quickly devolved into a 20-day odyssey in sub-zero temperatures with depleting food rations. Within 100 meters of the elusive summit, their journey—like all previous attempts—fell short of the goal. Heartbroken and defeated, the trio returned to their everyday lives. By September 2011, Anker had convinced his team to reunite and undertake the Shark's Fin once more, under even more extraordinary circumstances. Winner of the Sundance Film Festival Audience Award for Documentary, Meru is the story of that journey, an expedition through nature's harshest elements and one's complicated inner demons, and ultimately on to impossible new heights.
results.name: Meru film screening @ kendall cinema

Each and every Friday, we're proud to open the doors of our music school in Central Square for a FREE seminar, demo or meet-up. Hell, we’ll even throw a classical music concert or two. What's in store this week? Let's find out:


Learn about music composition and sound design for video games with Kedaar Kumar. In this workshop, we will focus on 2 software applications-- Ableton Live for creating audio and Unity for creating the game. Download Unity for free at 

unity3d.com/get-unity

Kedaar has been professionally doing audio for games since 2008 when he joined Harmonix as a Composer/Sound Designer for the Rock Band games franchise and then as an Assistant Audio Lead for the Dance Central games franchise.  While at Harmonix from[masked], he worked on 14 award-winning AAA titles.  Since then, Kedaar has moved on to teaching video game design, audiovisual programming and audio production at MIT-based NuVu Studio, an alternative learning center for middle and high school kids and also at The Binah School in Sharon, MA.
results.name: Sound Design for Video Games

results.description:
BPM is a compilation feature documentary that displays the story of the African-American community 1967-1975. Feat. Erykah Badu, Angela Davis, Talib Kweli.


The Black Power Mixtape examines the evolution of the Black Power Movement in the black community and Diaspora from 1967 to 1975. The film combines music, startling 16mm footage (lying undiscovered in the cellar of Swedish Television for 30 years), and contemporary audio interviews from leading African-American artists, activists, musicians and scholars.

results.description:
Reservations are required through llbean.com/dedham in order to attend.
Discover the beauty of nature at night as you paddle through calm waters under the glow of the summer moon. We believe a full moon enhances the beauty of these secluded waters and creates a truly memorable adventure. On this leisurely excursion, you'll paddle comfortable, stable kayaks and get a chance to experience nature up close. After a short paddling demonstration, your experienced guide will lead you on a revealing tour, sharing interesting facts about the area's history and the surrounding landscape. As the moon rises higher in the sky, you'll start to see the fascinating wildlife that emerges when the sun sets.

This spectacular tour only occurs during the weeks of the full moon and is a special adventure you won't want to miss. No prior kayaking experience is needed. All necessary paddling equipment is provided.

Price is $59 per person.
results.name: Full Moon Kayak Tour

It is a 5-minute walk from South Station (various T, bus, and train connections), a 5-minute walk from Park Street T Station (Green Line), and a 7-minute walk from State Street T Station (Blue Line).

Talented Psychic Medium Yulia Applewood presenting:

PSYCHIC DEVELOPMENT CLASS
  LEARN ABOUT SCRYING....

ALL TO SIGNUP[masked]-8288.

SCRYING CLASS AUGUST 28TH,[masked]PM.

TONIGHT'S AUGUST 7TH CLASS HAS BEEN POSPONED DUE TO MS.YULIA APPLEWOOD FAMILY EMERGENCY, THE SCRYING CLASS WILL BE FRIDAY AUGUST 28TH,[masked]PM.  WE DEEPLY APOLOGIZE FOR ANY INCONVINIENCE.
In this class students will learn the basics of psychism and mediumship in a safe and supportive environment. Students will discover their own innate psychic skill and talents through a series of exercises designed to gently open the third eye and make them aware of the unseen world around them. This class will focus on psychic protection and spiritual hygiene and spiritual awareness and will be instrumental in identifying and developing the individual psychic skills of each student. We will also explore the wonders of mediumship and connect with the realm of spirit through a small group séance. In each class students will have the opportunity to experiment with different psychic tools and techniques along with learning a brief history about each practice. In the first class we will discuss Tarot cards and learn the systems behind the symbolism in the cards, which make them such a useful tool in divination. We will also experiment with dowsing, using both rods and pendulums to answer simple questions and find lost items, we will introduce as well the ancient art of scrying on liquid, flame and crystal surfaces. We will also delve into palmistry and learn how to be prepared for certain changes in our own lives by studying some of the major lines on our hands. We will learn how to read tea leaves and throw bones as well. Both of these famous systems from antiquity have complex histories and variations that will also be discussed. Cost: $25.00

This spacious and comfortable restaurant, located on the border between Arlington and North Cambridge, offers the unbeatable combination of hip urban décor, tavern fare updated with a hint of big city sophistication, and a respectful nod to the neighborhood’s pre-Revolutionary War history.

Question most asked by diners: What the heck is Menotomy ?

Answer: The name given to Arlington by Native Americans when the village was established back in 1635 (it means “swift running water”)

http://www.menotomygrill.com/ So join us for a great night out -- hope to see you there!

It is important to actively and consciously attend to your energetic and spiritual bodies as well as your physical and mental bodies.  As we walk through our daily lives, we are constantly bombarded with others 'stuff' no matter how much we protect and stand clear...it is out there!  Not to mention our own 'stuff' we are dealing with - and the processing of our individual and collective growth (ascension).

PLEASE NOTE: This is to Welcome all New Members in the group and provide an opportunity for beginners in our Group to advance their learning. Request you NOT be late as we will not wait. We will talk about Cityscapes photography and how to take pictures of nightscapes in the city.

Where shall we meet? We will meet at the exact co-ordinates mentioned in the Location area. Please punch that in Google Maps (iPhone, Android, GPS devices). There are plenty of Parking areas around the location on Congress Street and Seaport Blvd. But lately due to construction they are mostly filled up. In case you have difficulty with street parking, please use your discretion and park at the paid parking areas mentioned below:

[masked] Congress St
Boston, MA 02210
[masked], [masked]

142 Northern Ave
Boston, MA 02210
[masked], [masked]

What should I bring? Of course your camera, preferably a DSLR, which has Manual Settings. Tripod is a must and please do carry an Intervalometer. (If you are not sure what it is, please try to procure one after reading the Group Blog.) You will need it down the line. You will need an UWA to Medium Wide lens anywhere between 14 mm to 70 mm. If you prefer doing strong abstracts you may get long range zooms. We will be talking about, Exposure, Aperture and ISO modes. We will also dwell on WB, RGB and straightening pictures in camera. For those who have intervalometers we will be talking about settings for star trails and the usage of the devices.

What are we going to do? Weather is absolutely clear and in the pleasant 60s in the evening. If you are interested we will be doing Star Trails with Cityscapes. It is challenging with bright lights and faint stars because of light pollution.

Do I need to know anything else? Yes. Please remember it is the night time and we will be spending time at the harbor area. Please be courteous to others when positioning your tripods or walking during the shot. You will be pretty close to the water, so take extra caution to see where you are stepping. Having members or the equipment getting drenched is something that we would love to avoid.

Our ultimate objective will be to learn and have fun.

Please check out pictures from our Meetup before:

http://www.meetup.com/GBNight/photos/25729806/
results.name: Back to Basics at Boston Fan Pier

Describing herself simply as a "Modern English Musician" Eliza Carthy, at 39, is only now beginning to reach the height of her musical powers. During a 25-year journey/career she has become one of the most dazzling and recognised folk musicians of a generation. She has revitalised and made folk music relevant to new audiences and has captured the most hardened of dissenters with canny, charismatic and boundary-crossing performance. Many of the current crop of young professional folk musicians owe their successes in part to her determination, standard-bearing and campaigning spirit.


Yorkshire-born and based in Edinburgh since 1997, Eliza, daughter of legendary British folk icons Martin Carthy and Norma Waterson, grew up immersed in the world of traditional English music. She has lived a life based on the philosophy that it is a genre worthy of and equal to any other, and that musicians need no boundaries and deserve no restrictions to what they do as artists.

Touring on and off since the age of fourteen, Eliza has appeared at a huge number of live events, multi-artist concerts and benefits from Robin Hood's Bay Village Hall to the Albert Hall. She has been a part of three Meltdowns at London's Southbank: those of Nick Cave, Patti Smith and Richard Thompson. This year she has been invited to curate her own three day event at Kings Place in London.

Eliza rarely performs solo, so this is a very rare treat, and we expect it to sell out and gather up a long waiting list! Be sure to make your reservations quickly.

results.description:
The Matt Flinner Trio - “Deeply Rooted New Acoustic Music”

In 2006, three musical pals decided to get together to play a few gigs; since then, the Matt Flinner Trio has been exploring new pathways and setting new standards for the bluegrass trio sound all around the U.S. and Europe.
Mandolinist Matt Flinner, guitarist Ross Martin and bassist Eric Thorin cover a wide variety of musical styles—all with the common ground of American roots music. Bluegrass, jazz and old-time music are all present here in their ways, along with a dose of classical chamber music composition and arrangement, as the members all draw from their wide array of musical loves, experiences and influences. These influences boil down into the trio’s own organic sound of New Acoustic music, or Modern String Band music, or Chamber Grass (music is getting harder and harder to label these days, isn’t it?). Whatever label you put on it, it is guaranteed to be fresh and original, and definitely something you’ve never quite heard before.

The trio began doing “Music du Jour” tours in 2006, in which each member of the group writes a new composition the day of the show, and all three new pieces are performed on that evening’s concert. After several of these tours the trio recorded its first CD, “Music du Jour,” on Compass Records in 2009. They have now performed over 130 “du Jour” shows around the U.S., and continue to explore new frontiers and new sounds in acoustic string band music. Their second CD, “Winter Harvest,” was released on Compass Records in 2012. Watch for their upcoming CD, “Traveling Roots,” in early 2016.

Ticket sales - https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-matt-flinner-trio-tickets-17935569772 - end Friday at 5pm. Get yours in time to have dinner before the show.

The concert series is partnered with two nearby restaurants, ideal for a pre-show meet-up. Discuss and arrange below. 

Patrons who show their server their eventbrite ticket for that evening's concert get 10% off dinner at the nearby 
Thai-E-Sarn Cuisine, 1377 Massachusetts Ave Arlington, MA 
(781)[masked]) 
http://www.thaiesarncuisine.com/ 
OR 
Szechuan's Dumpling, 1360 Massachuetts Ave Arlington, MA 
(781)[masked] 
https://www.facebook.com/SzechuansDumpling

Website https://sites.google.com/site/notlobmusic

Contact: [masked] - please DO NOT contact the venue.

Here's the game plan:

8:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

8:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

8:20 - Play!!!!!!

10:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing.

Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a light or dark "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

results.description:
The Party before the Parade!

A few years ago fellow Onyxbird, Kenny graciously offered to get us together for J'Ouvert (pronounced jouvay), which is an early morning street celebration and translates to, the breaking of the dawn. Participants wear costumes of their own design which are typically dark and/or humorous in terms of presentation. Everyone dances and sings to the soca, calypso music of the steel bands.


It is such a good time that it is now an Onyxbird tradition.


This is your chance to get up close and party with the bands and costumed revelers.

Wear something you don't mind getting dirty because the mud, oil, and paint will be flying.

We will meet on the steps of the Boys and Girls Club 15 Talbot Avenue 02124 https://www.google.com/maps/place/Boys+%26+Girls+Clubs+of+Boston/@42.2944582,-71.0864369,3a,75y,172h,90t/data=!3m7!1e1!3m5!1sODsyl6Ykmka5d6ysurgBwA!2e0!6s%2F%2Fgeo0.ggpht.com%2Fcbk%3Fcb_client%3Dmaps_sv.tactile%26output%3Dthumbnail%26thumb%3D2%26panoid%3DODsyl6Ykmka5d6ysurgBwA%26w%3D374%26h%3D75%26yaw%3D172%26pitch%3D0%26thumbfov%3D120%26ll%3D42.294458,-71.086437!7i13312!8i6656!4m2!3m1!1s0x89e37be5e9eee5ed:0xdebb4d50f2c43c65!6m1!1e1

Route begins at Harambee Park on Talbot Avenue

Turns right onto Blue Hill Avenue

Ends at Columbia Road and Blue Hill Avenue

This intersection is an entrance to Franklin Park

Here is the official band order for the Boston J'Ouvert 2015!

1: Euphoria J’ouvert/Five Star
2: Tempo
3: Ozone...
4: Happiest Band Alive
5: La Poo Carbit
6: Branches
7: J’ouvert Frontiers
8: Boston Jammers

results.description:
We will run down Comm Ave in the carriage lane to the Chestnut Hill/BC reservoir, with the option to run around the reservoir before turning around. This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course.

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM. 

The pace will vary depending on who shows up.  If there is a wide range of paces, we frequently end up splitting into smaller groups based on pace.  Even if your pace doesn't "match up" with anyone else, meeting up with the group and starting the run with everyone is a great way to get yourself out of bed on those early Saturday mornings!
results.name: Comm Ave long run  8-15+ miles

venue.name: Behind Au Bon Pain, look for a lawn & trail

results.description:
Please note the change of time. We are starting earlier in the morning to finish the run before it gets hot :-).  

Group run logistics: Please come prepared for a short run (or run/walk). Leave your bags, etc. at home or in your car so that you can run easily. Please make sure to arrive 10 minutes early to look for parking, find the location, etc. 
Coach will brief you at the beginning of the run about the distance and direct you through stretching exercises. It is absolutely OK to run/walk in the beginning. Many of us are first-time runners. So please don’t be shy :-). 

Program details:  TeamAIDAsha is a beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training and fund-raising program. We train runners for their full or half marathon races and runners raise donations for AID and Asha. Both beginner and experienced runners are welcome. Anyone is welcome to RSVP and join us for the group runs up to four time with no obligations. We request formal registrations after attending four group runs.

If you missed the information session you can get an overview of this training and fund-raising program from here.

Looking for more runners: We are always looking for more runners. If any of your friends, family members or colleagues to give us a try and join this meetup group.


Waiver: Lawyers make us do this :-).  By running with TeamAIDAsha program you are agreeing to our official waiver at: http://www.teamaidasha.org/waiver.html


About AID-Boston

Association for India's Development (AID) is a non-profit, volunteer movement committed to promoting sustainable, equitable and just development, especially at India’s grassroots. We meet once a week at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit AID-Boston at: www.aidboston.org

About Asha-MIT

Asha tries to catalyze socio-economic change in India through education of underprivileged children. We meet once a month at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit Asha Boston/MIT at: http://www.ashanet.org/mit/
results.how_to_find_us: Look for a group of runners and volunteers
results.name: Beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training run

results.description:
The Jaycee walking club!
I am extending you this invite to get you moving!
We meet Saturday mornings, 7:45 am, Fruit Street Mansfield, WW II Veterans Memorial Trail (Bike Path). Just past the airport. We go for just about a 4 mile walk, takes a little over an hour, and we have lots of fun. If you can’t do the 4 miles come and do what you can and work your way up. We usually have enough people to split up into sub-groups of leisure walkers and speedsters.

I use Map My Walk to keep track of our time and distance. This is a free app that you can download to your smartphone, should you want to start keeping track of your exercise, minutes and calories burned. It has a lot of features that I am sure you would have fun with.

If you can, let me know if you will be walking with us, so we don’t start without you. If we are all gathered before 8 we tend to just get going at that point.

If you are interested in joining our walking club, either this time or sometime in the future, please let me know and I will include you on that email list.
Laureen House [masked]
results.name: Foxboro Jaycees Walking Club

results.name: Joe's Coastal Ride

results.description:
Event Organizer: Lisa Robbins,[masked]

Sign-up Procedure


If you are interested in participating in this event, sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done hikes of comparable challenge within the past three months.

=========================

Read this hike's entire description and make sure you answer all of the questions in the pop-up box that appears when you RSVP.  The questions might not show up if you register from a phone or tablet, so if you don't see them, you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared, you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you sign up.

=========================

What We're Doing

We'll hike North Twin, South Twin and Galehead, three 4,000-footers north of the Pemigewasset Wilderness. The views from South Twin's wide open, rocky summit--a hiker's crossroads--are especially fine. We'll savor them over lunch before heading to Galehead. As an added bonus, we will likely meet up with another Random Meetup hiking from Garfield to Galehead.

Stats

This is a full day's hike, on classic White Mountains terrain: rocks, roots and water crossings. Stats per the White Mountain Guide Online:

Distance: 12.2 miles 
Elevation gain: 3932 feet 
Book time (miles/2 + gain/2k): 8 hours. This estimate doesn't include breaks.

Route includes: North Twin Trail; Twinway; AMC Galehead Hut; Garfield Ridge Trail; Gale River Trail.

We could alter our plans because of fatigue, weather, and/or other conditions. There is no guarantee we will complete the entire event as described here.

No guests are permitted. Dogs are permitted, with advance notice.

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you expect us to constantly wait for you while you putter around.

What to Bring

The usual for a summer hike: 2-3 liters of water, lunch, snacks, rain/wind protection, layers for cooler temps, headlamps (cuz you never know). Use this list to make sure you have what you need:

http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf **

**Exception to this list: No cotton.


We will be able to refill water at the Galehead Hut.

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment. Test and adjust it prior to the trip. 

Directions 

We'll meet in the parking lot at the Gale River Trailhead parking lot, on Gale River Rd. (FR 92), which runs south off Rte. 3 about 5 miles west of the center of Twin Mountain.

According to Google Maps, the trailhead is 150 miles and 2.5 hours drive time from Boston. Please give yourself some wiggle room to get there on time.

For customizable driving directions:

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]

=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to two of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Garfield and Galehead. We will use Garfield Trail to reach Garfield, the Garfield Ridge Trail to reach Galehad, and Gale River Trail to get back to the trailhead. The section between Garfield and Galehead has a few steep sections. Along the way we will stop at the AMC Galehead Hut.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months. 

Group size will be limited to 12 people.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there: 

http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/17-Mt-Garfield-4500

http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/44-Mt-Galehead-4024


Guests aren't permitted. Everyone must be a member of the group.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you. 

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 13.9 miles and climb about 4,400 feet. It should take an average hiker about 9 hours 15 minutes to complete. This event is considered ADVANCED because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. Use this link for the current weather forecast:

http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-71.31686&lat=44.30458#.VbV4eHjuh_Y


=== What to Bring === 

Use this link for a list of items needed for most three-season day hikes:

http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf 

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Gale River Trail parking lot on the east side of Gale River Road near Twin Mountain, NH, Since this is where we will end our hike we will leave a few cars there and drive to where will begin our hike. According to Google Maps this spot is about 148 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 23 minutes to drive there.

results.description:
This ride stages cars at the ferry terminal in Plymouth at 8am. We ride about 85 miles to P'town and take the 4:30 ferry back to Plymouth to close the loop and round out a fine day.

The math means doing 85 miles in 8 hours. I aim for a 12 mph moving average for 7 hours, so there is an hour of slack in the schedule. If winds are unfavorable, we can stage one car further south in order to shave off a few miles, nematode, and guarantee we make it the ferry.

Heads up items:
* Make sure you feel comfortable going the distance. The pace is not demanding, but the ferry ain't waiting.
* We will pick up the rail-trail around mile 40 and take it to mile 65. If at mile 40 somebody is noticeably dragging, they may choose this as a good turn around point.  At least there won't be riding back under time pressure.
* This ride is for determined and sociable turtles, not aloof hares!
* Ferry tickets book out so book early!

Route profile

Route plan.   Adding a few miles by taking less traveled roads.

Update:

Ignore this old one, which doesn't seem to want to be deleted.

Spotted on the route.   Appropriate.

results.description:
This is the reoccurring meetup for the weekly open water swims at Walden Pond. A well attended venue for triathletes training for races of all distances.

The gate opens at 7 a.m. and the Parking is right off of Walden St. Walden charges to park a their lot ($5) via a computerized parking attendant that takes cards. I'd recommend the annual pass if you think you're going to come to more meetups. Alternatively, It's a short distance from Concord High School. Some people avoid the parking fee by parking near Concord High School and then walk/ride their bike over to Walden. Click here for the map of the parking.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Across and back from the beach (Pictured above) is a little over a mile mile; a perfect distance for those training for 70.3 and Ironman races.

There are also some close to shore routes for people getting better acquainted with open water (see distance maps). We meet near the lifeguard house right on the beach closes to Walden street. Here is the map of walden pond.

This meetup is important because you always want to swim in groups if you can. Make certain that you look out for each other. Don't attempt to swim across the pond if you haven't trained for that distance. Always match up with someone or a group that swims your pace. The beauty of Walden is that you can swim very close to shallow water and get some good open water training in.

If there are people that are looking to go long for the first time, let me know in advance and I may be able to swim angel, or get a swim angel group together. That way we can do it in a controlled and safe environment.

For those that are really new and nervous about open water swimming, stay tuned for a beginners clinic that I'll put on in the summer.

results.name: Weekly Walden Open Water Swim

results.description:
Park on Linebrook Road, across from Marini Farm

Look for my car, a white Toyota 4runner (SUV)

Willowdale is part of a massive network of doubletrack and singletracks plowing into the forests of Wenham and the surrounding towns. It networks together with Bradley Palmer State Forest, Georgetown-Rowley State Forest, and Willowdale itself. The trails themselves are a mix of rolling, smooth, and rooted single and doubletrack that makes FANTASTIC riding. Plenty of climbs and technical challenges can be found, but the real high-point is the well-maintained and marked trails that go for miles with countless singletrack shoot-offs that re-merge onto the double track. One of the best rides in Massachusetts! You could ride here every day for a month and not experience everything.

Contact me for carpool

"LAST" SATURDAY SPEAK UP


If weeknights are difficult, take advantage of this Saturday meetup to build confident speaking skills. [We'll be meeting First Saturdays unless a holiday (like Labor Day) moves us to the preceding weekend]. Our Meetups are fast-paced and entertaining. Not intimidating. You are welcome to participate in our two-minute impromptu speaking exercises, but certainly not required. We have a 30-second “Round Robin” that everyone participates in (it’s fun and easy), and you’ll probably be asked to introduce yourself [talk briefly about an interest, or what brought you there]. Pretty basic, no surprises.  The only requirement is to enjoy yourself and get a sense of how the meetups run. [This session will supplement our usual Wed evening meeting, not replace it. Sessions start promptly, so please arrive a bit early.]  Please rsvp.

3rd Floor, Room 097. You must take the elevator by the security desk to access the floor.

Parking: If you can't find street parking, there is parking to the rear of the bldg. You will present your ticket to the security desk on your way out ($3), then insert the ticket at the gate as you exit.
(Don't park in the supermarket/Porter Square shopping center parking lot.)


See the "About Us" tab for more info.

results.description:
I am trying out this class for the first time hence the low price. It's a day for creating one absolutely stunning photograph.  

What is it about? 

We will meet at the studio for an introductory session in which I will explain a proven approach to creating a strong image, we will then travel to a local destination where you will put the approach into practice by creating a single photograph. 

Returning to the studio in the afternoon we will analyze our single image and look at post-processing it using a combination of Lightroom and Photoshop. 

What will you get out of this workshop

The aim is for you to walk away with a strong image to add to your portfolio. 

However, the process of achieving that aim is likely to prove more informative and valuable than the finished product.

During the day you will be forced to slow down and put into practice a series of steps that will definitely improve your way of seeing and composing the potential shot.

Who will benefit from this?

Anyone who has a reasonable grasp of their camera control, and who is looking for a better approach to creating strong photographs. 

The class will run from 10am to 5pm and because you will be guinea pigs for this experimental class the cost will be just $49.
results.name: The Expert Session: One day- one image!  Second Chance

Please visit  http://www.bullrunrestaurant.com/Bull_Run_Restaurant/Home.html   to see their menu and their history.

This will be a back road ride both ways with options to peel off on the return trip. Trip to Bull run will be approximately 60 miles and the return trip will be 45 with a gas stop. On the route back we will pass 2, 495, and 20 for options to peel off if you'd like to.

I've opened this ride up to 20 currently. If those with cb coms join, I will open it up to a larger head count.

Lowell Walks is a series of guided walking tours of downtown Lowell on Saturday mornings throughout the summer. Each tour begins at the Lowell National Historical Park Visitor Center at 10:00am. Tours are FREE, last about 90 minutes, involve moderate walking, and are conducted RAIN or SHINE.


On[masked], the topic is Lowell Monuments with guide Richard Howe, the official tour guide of the Lowell Cemetery and the Register of Deeds of the Middlesex North District. According to Lowell National Historical Park.."The people of Lowell have always commemorated members of the military, public servants and ethnic groups by erecting monuments around the city. Visit some of the most interesting and intriguing monuments on this walk!"

After the tour, there are many good restaurants in the area to go to for lunch

The Intelligent Investor by Benjamin Graham may be the greatest book ever written on the topic of investing. Warren Buffett claims the book changed his life. Natural resource investor Rick Rule adds you won't find a better resource for the time it takes to read it.

I propose we begin with chapters 1-4.

Albert

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us in the triangle between Magnolia and Thorndike Fields, just off the bike path.

results.description:
For another day of hiking, let's head to Walden Pond, where Thoreau famously spent so much time. Saturday is supposed to be hot and sunny, so let's take advantage!

The time we get home is flexible, but plan to arrive by 10:15! Tentatively, we'll plan to meet at Porter Square. However, we'll see where people would like to meet, and different groups can meet in different squares. If you have a car, please let me know- anyone who is coming but doesn't have a car will contribute toward paying for gas and the $10/car parking fee, and if you have a car, you come free. If you have a ZipCar membership, that works too. Walden's only a 20-30 minute drive away, so we should have plenty of time to explore.

Bring plenty of water and a packed lunch! I can't promise there will be too many places we can stop while we're hiking.

Looking forward to seeing you on Saturday!

NEW RSVP POLICY: Please RSVP if you plan to come. If you RSVP, I'll be waiting for you, so please show up! If you change your RSVP or ditch us within 48 hours of a meetup more than once per calendar year, we'll have to remove you from the group.  Two members have been dropped so far.  When you RSVP, you're making a commitment and taking a spot, so come. If you need to get a hold of me, my number is four four zero 488-5055.

results.description:
Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who decide to join get a $10 deduction from membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.  
Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Lily[masked]

 

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

 

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

results.description:
The Israelite nation was developing its own identity and culture, but they were on the brink of destruction. The people wanted to find respect and recognition on the world stage, to feel secure and powerful, and to be prosperous and comfortable in their own homes.  But this was at a time when everyone was doing what was right in their own eyes.  Doesn't sound so different from today, does it?  But God wants to show us a better way--a man who will do all his will, a king after God's own heart.

Join us as we investigate the story of 1 Samuel and the different lessons for us!

results.name: Check Out 1 Samuel!

results.description:
This social activity is completely voluntary, and not-for-profit: no compensation of any kind is required or expected for participation. By boarding my boat, you explicitly agree to assume full personal responsibility for your own safety and well-being, and indemnify me against any legal liability.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

Sailing Info 

Please read disclaimer at the bottom of the page before you RSVP

Who can come
Everybody is invited.
I will be skippering the boat in and out of the mooring field and will be taking over when needed. Once we are in clear waters we will be taking turns at the tiller.


Where
We will be sailing in the Boston inner harbor, and might venture out and sail around one of the Boston Harbor Islands.


What 

- we will sail on
Boston 27 (Based on Soling) , Sonar, or Soling. You can learn more about these boats here: http://www.bostonharborsailing.com/fleet_boston27.html


- to expect
A laid back and safe sailing adventure to the extent it is possible on the racing boat without the engine or bathroom in the busy harbor.

In perfect conditions Boston 27 is a comfortable boat to sail on, but in the strong winds boat will lean and you might get splashed. On a windy day be prepared to pull on the ropes, move around, get splashed, and not have much down-time.

Be warned that it can get stressful at times and we will need to react quickly. . Remember, these boats don’t have engines and we will have to rely on the wind power. During stressful situations it is important to stay calm and to work as a team.

- will be on the boat
Two flotation pillows and four life jackets.


- is important
Safety will be our number one priority. I will give a safety crash course once we are on the boat. I recommend that everyone wears a life jacket.


- to bring
Sunscreen, hat, sunglasses, water, and a cell phone. Sailing Boston 27 or Soling on a windy day can get you splashed. I would recommend bringing a change of clothes and getting a waterproof case for you cell phone or wrapping it in a plastic bag.


- I will bring
My own gear, two-way UHF floating radio pre-programmed with the sailing club and Coast Guard channels and a winch handle to help tighten the sails.


Disclaimer
Sailing can be and will be stressful at times.
It is unlikely but is possible to sustain an injury during sailing. I will try to ensure that we have a safe sailing adventure but be advised that getting scratched or hurt occasionally is part of the sport.

results.name: Sail Around Boston Harbor

results.description:
Join us for your Dare to Dream Party, our very first Meetup!


• Do you allow yourself to dream big?

• Do you believe you can have what you want?


Having a big dream that lights you up and believing that you can have it are equally important.

Usually what happens is that you get excited about what you want but you don't fully believe you can have it or you don't know how to get there so you 'water down' your vision so it seems doable.

or...

You do believe you can have it but you believe it takes lots of hard work, sacrifice, overcoming the past, becoming who you are not, etc. etc.

Neither of these ways really honors you and that's why it's been challenging to manifest what you want.


You deserve to have what you want in a way that's aligned with who you uniquely are. In fact, you couldn't have the ideas for your dream if it wasn't possible for you to bring them into physical reality.

==> This Meetup's Intention <==


So for this meetup, let's get together to share what our dreams are and hopefully we'll inspire each other to dream up... to expand our visions.


Then we'll talk about the HOW... what you need to do moment by moment to bring your vision into physical reality. We'll talk about the stages of manifestation so that you know (and can celebrate) that you're vision is becoming real.


We'll also talk about fears and doubts... how to embrace them so that they serve your vision creating/living process.


It's time dear Superheroes to express yourself fully and live your dream. It's the ultimate act of self-love.... to let yourself be you by creating what you're inspired to create.

Are you willing to love yourself this much?

==> Refreshments <==

It's a party to celebrate you. We'll need munchies. I'll provide bottled water. Please bring whatever you're inspired to share - your favorite sweets, your favorite kale salad, fresh veggies, juice, potato chips, etc. :-)

==> Attire <==

Come dressed in whatever outfit that lets you feel naturally you. If this means you dress to the nines, wear a tank and shorts or something in between, that's fine.
results.name: Dare to Dream Party

results.description:
Join us for a monthly meetup to play some 18xx games.

Contact Dave M (click the link, then click "Message") for the address.

For the uninitiated, 18xx games are a subset of train games with a focus on stock-market and tile laying mechanics in the 19th century. Players start-up and manage (or mismanage…) railroads with the winning condition being money in the player’s hands at the end of the game. These games are all long, heavy, and feature little randomness leading many to consider them some of the most rewarding games to play. For more information please visit the wikipedia page at (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/18XX_games) or the BGG Wiki page at (https://boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/18xx). You can find a version of the rules for 1830 on the mayfair website (http://mayfairgames.com/mfg-shop3/rules/MFG1830-Rules-V1_0.pdf) (focus on the 1830 classic rules) if you are interested in getting a head start.

For this meetup, we will try and get somewhere between 2-3 games in over the session. Players of all skill levels are invited to join us and we are happy to teach new players the system as well as teach new games in the system (I am still fairly new to the system myself).

PLEASE NOTE: Since the focus of this meetup is on longer games and the headcount limit is low (5 players/1 table) please be considerate when RSVPing for this event. Please try to give notice to those on the waitlist if you expect to have to drop your RSVP. Additionally, since there is only one table and the games are long, please try to arrive on time, since 1 person late will delay the whole group.

Please contact Dave M (click the link, then click "Message") for the address as well as any other information.
results.name: Monthly 18xx in Waltham

results.description:
Join us on a photo tour as we photograph the Southern Maine Coastline. We will visit several areas looking photographing coastal landscapes and lighthouses. We will photograph from 1pm till sunset and stay a little longer for night photography.

We will carpool from Kittery/York area. or meet directly in Portland Maine.  

Our first stop will be Portland Head Lighthouse. The dramatic rocky coastline, pounding surf, lighthouses, fishing harbors, lobster boats etc provides us with unlimited subjects to photograph. I will also point out any wildlife we see.

We will stop at many locations across the Maine Coast till sunset. We will continue after dark for 1-2 hours.

This trip is cosponsored with the Nature Photographers of New England and Beyond Meetup Group

http://www.meetup.com/Nature-Photographers-New-England/


TIMELINE:


12 PM: Meet for optional carpool in Kittery or York.

1 PM: Meet across the street from entrance of Portland Head Lighthouse .

You can meet either place in Kittery/York or Portland .

We will head south and stop at many location along the way. We will shoot till sunset 7:30PM: Sunset

After Sunset: We will continue after dark photographing including Nubble Light

PAYMENT:

Payment can be made by check to Slonina Photography.

We also accept Visa, Mastercard, Discover, and American Express.

If you prefer to use credit card you can call our office at (508)[masked] or use the online shopping cart.

http://www.sphotography.com/new-england-one-day-photo-tours-and-workshops/

What you will learn:

Our job is not only to help you create beautiful images and have fun but also teach skills and techniques you can use to take your photography to the next, higher level! Attendees will have a solid understanding of many basic and advanced principles related to nature photography.

Weather:

In the event of pouring rain we will reschedule for the next day (Sunday).

Lodging:

Participants are responsible for their own lodging (if necessary). It would recommend you stay in the Portsmouth NH, Kittery or York Maine.

Cancellation:

If you cancel before 30 days of departure you will receive a full refund.

If you cancel within 30 days you will not receive a refund unless we are able to fill the spot.

Who should attend:

Anyone with a interest in photography from a beginner to professional photographer who has a love of being outdoors and nature.

Transportation:

Car pooling will be encouraged. I will be driving a large passenger van which can fit 6 photographers and their gear.

Food:

Participants will be responsible for their own meals. We will visit a local restaurant.

About Me:

John Slonina is a professional nature photographer and photo tour and workshop leader. He has been photographing the nature for over 25 years. He has been published in multiple books, magazines, and calendars. He has a love of natural history as well. You will receive education not just in photo technique, but also in the natural world. Understanding the natural world not only increases your appreciation of nature but also helps you become a better nature photographer.

results.name: 1 DAY INSTRUCTIONAL PHOTO TOUR: MAINE COAST

results.description:
Fitness doesn’t need to be intimidating or extreme, but it does need to produce good RESULTS! Come join TFW Boston for an after-work happy hour… errr I mean workout. Our workouts make will make you BETTER, not just tired, and our fitness familia will help you enjoy your time and ENCOURAGE you to give your best!


What to expect:

A challenging, motivating, and downright fun environment for training - perfect for after a long day of work.

TFW signature workout as seen on ESPN, The New York Times, and Boston Fitness Magazine, which has created world champions in multiple professional sports, and is individually-adapted for every person that takes part, even beginners!

Effective warm-ups to get you in the zone, and energetic intervals to invigorate mind and muscle.

Sweat, smiles, and lots of high-fives.


What NOT to expect:

Bootcamp instructors barking in your face.

Workouts that put exhaustion before results and safety.

Participants that are there just to feel like they’re better than someone else.


If you want to have fun and lose fat, gain strength, and improve your confidence and health, this is the place to be. Please bring water, workout clothes and shoes, a hand to high-five with, and a friend.

results.description:
(A set of 6 Saturday classes)

Rapier – The word evokes images of duels, high adventure, and swashbuckling. Have you had a desire to learn how these swords were used in combat during the Renaissance era? Much more than shouting “En Garde!” and assuming a guard stance; competent warriors fought with systems that included various ways to attack and defend, footwork, timing, and even rules of dueling, all based on a sophisticated understanding of body mechanics, mathematics and philosophy.

The 16th century was a period of change for the sword. No longer relegated to the battlefield; the sword changed as its wear became commonplace in society. Blades slimmed and guards became more elaborate as the sword evolved into a nimble thrusting weapon worn by commoner and noble alike. As a result, a number of fencing schools opened to capitalize on their growing popularity. The golden age of rapier study dawned around 1550; numerous masters publishing fencing system manuals over the century to follow, with topics including rapier, off-hand companions such as the dagger, buckler and cape, long sword, quarterstaff, pole arm, dagger alone, and grappling.

Our six-week Novice Rapier course will introduce the basic techniques and vocabulary of rapier fencing, enabling students to begin their study of period combat and the Art of Defence. The course will be taught by Charles and Robert, rapier scholars and Schole of Defence instructors.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

We invite you to come join the scholars and combatants of our Schole!

(The price shown is for the set of all six classes [August 22, 29, and September 5, 12, 19 and, 26] and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  Class materials will be sent via email before the first session.)

results.description:
Social In Boston Presents:

BOSTON ROOF DECKS TOUR

The Summer of 2015 is going to be a great one for the members of Social In Boston! One part of what makes it so great is our weekly roof deck tour. Each and every Saturday we'll be visiting a different roof deck for food, drinks, relaxation, and socializing. Please the details carefully every week, as the details are going to change. Some venues have better times to visit than others, and as already stated, each week will be in a different location...

Our Fifteenth Stop...

The Baseball Tavern is located just a short fly ball from fenway Park. Their Roof Top Deck, overlooking Fenway Park, is one of the most popular fun spots Boston has to offer, from the first pitch on Opening Day until the final out is recorded in the Fall Classic. Whether it's before, during, or after a Red Sox game, or just anytime you're looking for some fun, stop at The Baseball Tavern for a good time.

On the menu: Click here for the menu.

GETTING THERE

The Baseball Tavern is at 1270 Boylston Street, Boston Ma, 02215.

Click here <a>directions on Google</a>. The nearest T stops are Fenway and Kenmore stations on the Green Line.

Parking: There are a lot of places to park near Fenway. There is on street parking if you can find it, otherwise, check this Google map for parking near The Baseball Tavern.

See you there Socialites!

~Matt

results.description:
It's time for the Boston Carnival. I'm certain the high energtic pulsing beats will get you moving on your feet or in your seat and you will be amazed by the beautiful, colorful and elaborate costumes. Join in the fun, wave your flag or any flag, while enjoying the dancing in the streets of this colorful and festive celebration, which is rooted in African traditions.

We'll start the day watching the festivities from the parking lot of Boston Latin Academy along the Warren Street side of the school which is diagonally across from Walgreen's and at the intersection of Townsend, Warren and Quincy Streets. Then head over to Franklin Park around 3 PM, where you can buy delicious Caribbean cuisine to eat while watching the parade wind its way to the end.

The parade steps off at 1 PM from Martin Luther King Blvd and Humboldt Avenue in Roxbury then proceeds along Warren Street through Grove Hall along Blue Hill Ave ending in Dorchester's Franklin Park which is at the corner of Blue Hill Avenue and Columbia Road. The food stalls/vendors are located in front of the Zoo, which features many different Caribbean and American cuisines.  Arts and Crafts, music & video CDs, other items are also available.

Here's a link with the parade route. http://www.bostoncarnival.org/pdf/map.pdf

Here is a Boston Globe article about the 2010 Boston Caribbean carnival by former Onyxbird, Meghan Irons.

After 11 AM it will be impossible to drive to and park on Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Blvd, Warren Street, Humboldt Avenue and Blue Hill Avenue.

So either get there early or take the bus which travels on Blue Hill Avenue or Humboldt Avenue, then walk a few blocks to our meetup spot.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet up on the grass in front of the Boston Latin Academy on the Warren Street side. This a great place to view the parade.
results.name: Boston Onyxbirds Jump Up at Boston Carnival

results.description:
Kevin Gage will be doing a presentation on SQL injection at the next Meetup.


SQL injection "is a code injection technique, used to attack data-driven applications, in which malicious SQL statements are inserted into an entry field for execution."  We will discuss and show examples of real world SQL Injection uses.

Here are the details:


1. WHAT: Learning trails - Common Weakness Enumeration  (CWE): SQL injection


2. WHEN: August 29th, 2015 (this Saturday) from 1:00 PM - 3: 00 PM


3. WHERE:

We'll meet at the Braintree Library in the small conference room upstairs:


Thayer Public Library
798 Washington Street
Braintree, MA

4. WHY: Improve our technical knowledge and network. (Bring your business cards!)

5. ToDo: Please review the following articles: 


a) https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SQL_Injection</a>

b) <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SQL_injection">https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SQL_injection

c) https://technet.microsoft.com/en-US/library/ms161953%28v=SQL.105%29.aspx?f=255&MSPPError=-2147217396

6. Format: Presentation, demonstration, programming and discussions. This is a techie-led event. Bring your laptops!

7. Misc: Bring others interested with you!
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be waiting upstairs in the small conference room in the Children section. If you do not find us, ask the librarian about the small group meeting in the conference room upstairs.
results.name: Learning trails - Common Weakness Enumeration  (CWE): SQL injection

Want to know what it's like working on a day to day basis with Ocean City Development? Here's your chance.


We will be featuring Andrew Chapman of Cameron Real Estate Group. Andrew has been an agent for 8 years and has had experience working at both a smaller niche real estate office and a larger franchise run office. He officially joined our Team in November as an agent and has been working our leads ever since.

On the call, we'll be discussing:

1. Life before Ocean City Including:

a. Day to Day Schedule

b. Number of leads his previous brokerages provided him

c. Number of appointments per week he was averaging prior to joining

d. Number of deals closed per year(on average)

e. The hesitations that he had prior to joining us

And


2. Life With Ocean City Including:

a. What his day to day schedule looks like now

b. The number of leads per week that we supply him with

c. The number of appointments per week that he averages now that he is with us

d. Volume of deals he has closed since the transition

e. The answer to the question of whether his intiial hesitation about joining us had any validity

This webinar is meant to be an inside look behind the walls of Ocean City and is presented in order to give viewers an unbiased look at both the positives and the negatives of our company from a 3rd party perspective.

Please register for the webinar at: http://ewebinars.com/webinar/?trackingID1=XXXXXXXX&trackingID2=YYYYYYYYY&landingpage=default&expiration=default&memberid=9778&webid=c2om6skxhq

results.description:
Paddle boarding is becoming my new thing! 

We will rent with www.capeannsup.com. A half day rental is $50 for four hours, but you can purchase 10 hours for $100, and it doesn't expire at the end of the season. Thus, if you fall in love with paddle boarding and want to continue to go, it would be easy to do for less time and less cost. Based on our experience, 2-3 hours is way more than enough. 

*After you RSVP you MUST call Cape Ann SUP and reserve your rental for this day.* Please ALSO remember that if you sign up and later decide cancel, that you should also remember to cancel your rental with Cape Ann SUP as well. 

You can tell them it is the MeetUp group with RENEE. They will ask for your phone number; in the event that they don't let people go out due to weather they offer to call you beforehand. 

We will be meeting at the Essex location at 35 Dodge Street. You will come to a big parking lot and they will have a small set-up near the water. Please try to get there by 12:45 PM. Come early, get your sunscreen on, etc. We are going out later in the day this time around because of the tide. 

Remember, that if you RSVP and don't bother to show up, you will be marked as a NO SHOW. I don't care if you change your mind, even if it's at the last minute, just be polite enough to let me know. There's nothing that I hate more than waiting for people who never come. 

PS I also have set the RSVP's so that people can not add others. This is because in my experience small groups of people will hold up the RSVP list and then not show or cancel at the last minute. If you want others to join they will need to join either North Shore Women's Group or Casual Kayakers first. 

AS A CONDITION OF ATTENDING THIS MEETUP, YOU AGREE TO: Hold harmless, and indemnify the organizers and their relations and heirs, and all members and participants of the Meetup group from any and all claims for injury, illness, death, and/or property damage including those caused by negligence, ignorance, inexperience and other reasons. You also agree to assume all mental, physical, financial, and/or other risk associated with this meetup. Kayaking, camping, hiking, bicycling, and other activities pose inherent risks and dangers. Participation in these activities is voluntary and dependent upon your own personal judgment. As organizers we make no claims regarding any expertise for this outing. This is not a guided tour. In the interest of safety, consuming alcohol before or during any Casual Kayakers event is not allowed. Wearing of Lifejackets (PFD's) is required when paddling with this group.
results.how_to_find_us: 35 Dodge Street, Essex, end of the parking lot
results.name: Stand Up Paddle Boarding Essex

results.description: Hello merrymakers, We are set for Aug. 29th at 1 PM-a luncheon at Kennedy's Public House of Norwood. It is a part of the Hampton Inn. The beef tips are raved about and the menu is varied to suit all tastes. I spoke with Zack who was warm and friendly and happy to offer separate checks and to allow for twelve members. I think this will be a fun break in the day for everyone. If you are bringing a friend, I now have it set up so that you may request a plus 1 to accommodate your guest. Do be prepared to tip between 18-20% in thanks to the staff. Arrive on time and if you change your mind in attending, go back to where you clicked yes and change it to no so that those on the wait list can move up. There is never any need to let us know why you can't attend or changed your mind as that is expected. Be on time so that we can all be seated at the same time. I am chomping at the bit to see you'll. http://www.kennedyspublichouse.com/

results.name: Boston Carnival

results.description:
Organizer: Joe Ciarcia -[masked]

=========================

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself or others at risk so consider this before you decide to participate.

=========================

***** NEW SIGNUP PROCEDURE *****
If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months. (similar in this case means similar difficulty in terms of distance and elevation, prior night hiking experience is not required)

What We're Doing...

What are we doing? Simply one of the best hikes in the world and we're going to aim to be on the summit of Liberty a little before sunset (7:28 PM), and then enjoy the rest of the ridge via full moon (moonrise is at 7:21 PM). Note: we will not hit the OBP parking lot until around 1:30 AM to 2:30 AM, possibly later. Keep this in mind. Also, be on time! We will not wait for stragglers as this hike's start time is very time critical.


Use this link for more information about the summits and trails:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/6-Mt-Lafayette-5260--7-Mt-Lincoln-5089

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/18-Mt-Liberty-4459--25-Mt-Flume-4328

Guests are not permitted.


Dogs are permitted - Dogs must have a flashing LED collar for this hike. be sure to bring a leash in case you need to use it and a copy of their current rabies vaccination.

Trip Summary...

Distance: 14.5 miles
Vertical: 5,693 feet.
Book Time: 10 hours and 6 minutes

The point of this trip is to enjoy a time of day when we're usually not up on top of a summit. As such, I expect the completion time for this hike to be longer than book time as we'll probably linger on the summits a littler longer, however, when we are moving we will be moving at a faster than book time pace (moving average in the 1.7 to 2 MPH range (book time pace for this hike without rests would be 1.4ish MPH).

This event is considered to be ADVANCED because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain. We could alter our plans because of fatigue, weather, and/or other conditions - there is no guarantee we will complete the entire event as described here.

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

You need to become self-reliant by learning about the route and potential hazards since you are ultimately responsible for your own safety.

What to Bring...


EVERYONE MUST BE CARRYING TWO HEADLAMPS WITH FRESH BATTERIES (and yes I will be checking). One of those headlamps must be LED based. Don't forget the layers as well as it's likely to be colder than your standard day hike.


Use this link for a list of items needed for a three season day hike (exception to list, NO COTTON):

• http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf


Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

Weather...

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.

Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.16074668800047&lon=-71.64432606299965&site=all&smap=1#.U3esRMeMFGE

Directions...


We will meet at the Old Bridal Path Trailhead to spot cars which is located off of Rt. 93 after exit 34A (do not get off at exit 34A). According to Google Maps this meeting spot is 137 miles from Boston and it should take about 2 hours and 7 minutes to drive there. Since this is where we will finish the hike will leave a few cars there and drive to the spot were we will start the hike. 

Use this link for customizable driving directions:

• <a>https://www.google.com/maps/dir//44.142066,-71.681358/@44.1424003,-71.7500904,12z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m3!4m2!1m0!1m0</a>;


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride. If you do share a ride be sure to share the expenses (gas and tolls).

Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer...

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
results.name: NH4K - Franconia Ridge Sunset/Full Moon Hike Take 2

results.description:
Co posted to several Meetups. 46 signups so far between the groups!

THIS IS A DIFFERENT ROUTE FROM THE LAST TIME.

CHECK IN AT 2:30, put your backpacks in the lockers, get your tickets, and Meet & Greet then at 2:45 we're OFF!   
   
For the 6th time, at this popular & incredible gem of a Museum meetup location. We meet just inside the main entrance & head (this time) to the elevators area by the stairs to the 2nd floor. Then we go into the Tobey Gallery right there & pass through to the Fancy Silverware exhibition. We continue on past the masterpieces portraying George Washington and Napoleon, to the painting called Feigned Flight (image below-- the man in the painting who is pursuing her is not in this image which defines it), Ingres' Studies for the Martyrdom, Moreau's Jacob and the Angel (image below), The incredible Call to Arms mini study sculpture by Rodin, Dante Rossetti, & Burne-Jones's works. 
   
NOTE-- hosts will not linger at some of the galleries but PASS RIGHT THROUGH  others because there will be MUCH MORE to see after this.  So GO! stay with the company. This is a meetup enjoy the company; if you want to come earlier to linger at your fav places do that then.  

At 4 PM regroup at the elevators and head back downstairs to the Surrealist Art (follow the hosts) --note the sculpture Detroit Queen. Loop through there and get to the Picassos and the last room back towards the entrance including the Bathers by Renoir --then meet us again back at the open area cafeteria. 

If you do lose us or get tired, look for others in the meetup at the cafeteria back on the first floor, where we gather again and leave AT 4:45 to the patio event at Legal Sea Foods. That is a ten minute walk through Harvard Yard.   
   
ADMISSION free for Cambridge residents with a drivers license. Otherwise it's $15. Backpacks not allowed. You can store them in lockers across from the admissions area, alternately there is another locker area down one floor from there.

http://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-7he8jlARtuM/VJmDezIHhRI/AAAAAAAEzwg/v9Rn311tEa8/s288/DSC00954.JPG
results.how_to_find_us: Just inside the main entrance at 2:30 I will be dressed in all Blue.
