results.description:
(Later gather at the cafeteria near the entrance by 4:45 then we will go to the Legal Sea Foods Patio across Harvard Yard  and regroup there at 5 PM.) 

You must check backpacks at the lockers opposite admission area; or there are more lockers downstairs. gather with the other groups there and we're off on the sketching at 2:45 after meet & greet.

Harvard Art Museums allows sketching but only with pencil no pens, no charcoal. THIS WILL BE CO POSTED WITH 2 OTHER MEETUPS, going to see the paintings. You will occasionally find some fabulous sketches on display there. You can sketch sculptures (any angle), other patrons admiring the paintings, the architecture of the interior of this brand new building, or each other sketching. (Renzo Piano group are the famous architects)

Folding stools are available ask at the admissions area. Otherwise there are very few places to sit so prepare to sketch on foot.

Admission is $15 but if you are a Cambridge resident it's free. This is a hidden gem of the Boston area and well worth the cost of admission. AND of course we get to MEETUP!

You'll have plenty of socializing opportunities (there are already 46 signups with the other groups and climbing) AND there is an after event at the Legal Sea foods PATIO across Harvard yard at 5 PM. --Where the other signups are also going.

results.description:
Sign-up for the Webinar at: https://www.innerengineering.com/online/free-meditation-webinars-2?signinsrc=Meetup-NewEngland

***REGISTRATION closes 45 minutes prior to the webcast.***  Please make sure you sign-up on our website at least 45 mins prior to the webcast to receive your live log-in link via email. 

(Technical Support:[masked]) 


Isha Kriya Guided Meditation-

A lot of people find it really difficult to calm the mind and settle the body for meditation when they first try it. Too many people get frustrated and give up on meditation before they can experience its many benefits.

These 1-hour guided sessions offer a simple, but powerful kriya practice that aligns your mind, body, and inner-energies to easily and naturally become meditative. Once meditative, your experience of the life within you and the world around you becomes much deeper and richer. Daily activity becomes effortless and joyful. 

You can easily learn this 12-to-18 minute Isha Kriya process in one session and practice on your own, or return to class to ask questions and deepen the experience with the group. Benefits of regular practice include improving health, energy and vitality; enhancing mental focus, memory and clarity; reducing stress and establishing a deep sense of peace and inner balance.

Isha Kriya is a gentle, seated practice, which can be practiced in a chair. No previous meditation experience is necessary.

The Isha Kriya process was developed by realized yogi, Sadhguru Vasudev. Sadhguru is renowned for his powerful yoga and meditation programs, as well as thriving humanitarian initiatives. He has been hosted to speak and offer meditations at numerous global leadership forums, businesses and universities, including the United Nations, the World Economic Forum, the British House of Lords, TED, MIT, and the World Peace Congress.

This free session will be facilitated by a trained Isha Kriya instructor. Contact: [masked],[masked] for more information about Isha USA or this session.

For more on Sadhguru and Isha, visit IshaUSA.org/blog
results.name: Isha Kriya Guided Meditation--FREE Class (Online Webinar)

results.description:
Pokeno time again, and Diane W will be our hostess - thanks Diane!
Please bring:
$10 in quarters
a $10 unwrapped gift for the gift table
about 25 little markers for your card (bingo chips, flat decorative marbles, pennies, etc)

4:00 pm: arrive, settle in
4:15 pm: place dinner order
4:30 pm: first card is called!

Please be aware that the temperature in the room varies from very chilly when the AC is on, to very warm when it automatically shots off. I don't know why these function rooms can't get it right, but it is an ongoing issue......so it's best to dress in layers. Just saying!

Also, please bring cash as it is easier to settle the bill that way. We use the x1.27 formula to figure out food, tax and tip. And thank you ladies in advance for always being generous tippers! They do not charge us for the room, so please do not bring in outside food - they prefer that we purchase our food and drink there. We'll have the magnetic board for "visual cues" - it really helps!
And I've asked them for a different table arrangement...Do you guys remember how well it worked at Bertucci's in the horseshoe? I've asked them to do that at Bickford's and they were pleased to try that out...so we'll see....!
results.name: Play Pokeno!  Sat. 8/29 BICKFORD'S 4:00 pm

results.description:
Let's go kayaking on the Charles River in Cambridge!

Charles River Canoe and Kayak has a location near Kendall Square in Cambridge (right on the Red Line!) where we can rent kayaks and canoes and take a trip down the Charles.

Single kayaks cost $15 per hour, or you can share a double for just $10 per hour each!  We plan to take a 2-hour trip.

Here's their website for more information, and directions are reprinted below:  https://www.paddleboston.com/kendall.php

We'll spend a couple of hours on the river, then head somewhere for dinner (location to be decided...plenty of restaurants in the Kendall area).

Directions to Charles River Canoe and Kayak in Kendall Square  (500 Broad Canal Way, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142)


Walking from the Red Line (Kendall/MIT):  Take the MBTA Red Line to Kendall/MIT. Walk straight through the Marriott Hotel lobby, exiting onto Broadway (not marked). Turn right on Broadway. At the first intersection (Third Street, opposite the "Steaming Globe" sculpture), turn left onto Third St.Take the first right onto Broad Canal Way. The Rental Center is located 100 yards down this street, at the corner where it turns right. Total walking distance is between one-quarter and one-half mile (5-10 minutes).

Address of Parking Garage for GPS:  350 Kendall Street, Cambridge.  (Latitude N 42°[masked]'; Longitude W 71°[masked]')

Walking from the Parking Garage to the Rental Center:  Exit at Kendall Street (the garage entrance), and follow the signs for Canoe & Kayak @ Kendall Square. Walk 100 feet along the sidewalk (about 1 minute). The Rental Center is on the left.


**Charles River Canoe and Kayak CLOSES when it rains.  Good weather is expected on Saturday, but if the forecast changes for that day then I will send an update for an alternate indoor activity...probably bowling...as soon as possible!**
results.how_to_find_us: We'll meet at the Kendall Square Red Line station.
results.name: Kayaking on the Charles!

results.description:
Come join  me in enjoying another Cidery right in our back yard in Somerville MA they are open very limited hours and close at 8pm on Saturday's so come join me in trying some cider!! We can then head to the Independent  down the street for dinner afterwards 

the last tour of the day is at 4:30 so if you want to do a tour please arrive by 4:15!! Because i work on Saturdays i will not be able to get there for the tour but will be there between  5:00 ond 5:30!!

We are committed to making creative and distinctive  crafted cider using fresh pressed apples and high-quality, all-natural ingredients. We believe cider making is more art than sc ience, the process requiring patience over expediency. Bantam strives to be modern, our approach for-ward looking. We don’t believe cider must fit neatly into one standard style. Instead we want to push the creative process and elevate cider as the versatile, complex and interesting choice it deserves to be.
results.name: brewery tour #10 Bantam Cider

results.description:
This trailer looked like it would be a riot.   A druggie who is actually a sleeper assassin/agent.   I am so there!

Showtime is at 5:55.  A little early for this group but the next show time would make the after event too late.    It is showing upstairs, so we will gather at the tables by the big windows at the top of the escalators.  I will be at the theater by 5.   Be aware that some of the ticket takers are not letting people upstairs right away.   We will be heading in for seats at 5:30.  If you don't get there before then, just head to the theater.   We try to sit in the middle rows.   Also we will meet in the hallway after the movie for a bit before those who are interested head out for dinner and drinks. 

Tickets are on sale on Fandango now.

In general, I arrive at the theater an hour before the show to start gathering people, and we head in for seats about 30 minutes before the show, so we can sit together. This also allows us to take turns getting snacks, etc., before the previews start.  It also allows for any unexpected, last minute changes at the theater.  Although fairly infrequent, having wiggle room to exchange tickets, etc. is VERY helpful.

If you miss the group ahead of time, come find us after. We gather in the hallway outside of the theater we just saw the movie in, to discuss the film a bit, allow for restroom breaks and to get a head count of all those who would like to go out after for drinks and munchies.

$$$$Managing the after event is much easier if everyone brings cash, so please plan ahead if you want to go out with the group after.  We will be splitting one bill for the group. No separate checks.$$$

One more thing, please keep your rsvp's up to date so I can plan the after event and know who to look for.  Thanks!

Movie Details:

Release date: August 21, 2015        


Studio: Lionsgate

Director: Nima Nourizadeh

MPAA Rating: N/A

Screenwriter: Max Landis

Starring: Kristen Stewart, Topher Grace, Bill Pullman, John Leguizamo, Jesse Eisenberg, Connie Britton, Walton Goggins, Tony Hale

Genre: Comedy, Action

Duration: N/A

Copyright Holder: N/A

Copyright: N/A

Plot Summary:

"American Ultra" is a fast-paced action comedy about Mike (Eisenberg), a seemingly hapless and unmotivated stoner whose small-town life with his live-in girlfriend, Phoebe (Stewart), is suddenly turned upside down. Unbeknownst to him, Mike is actually a highly trained, lethal sleeper agent. In the blink of an eye, as his secret past comes back to haunt him, Mike is thrust into the middle of a deadly government operation and is forced to summon his inner action-hero in order to survive.

results.description:
If you are not on the RSVP list but would like join us, please select that you would like a spot. If at least 5 others agree to purchase tickets, I can select one person's name for the rest to enter in their "sit next to" section, and then you can purchase your tickets and sit together.

https://www.thedinnerdetective.com/boston/


Any info you need can be found at that site. Some people say this isn't much of a murder mystery show, more of a comedy show, and some say the food isn't that great...BUT there are some great reviews and I am curious so I will be checking this out and I can fit up to 9 other people at a table with me. If we have more than 10, we can arrange those people to be together at a separate table.

Business casual or dressy casual is absolutely required. No T-shirts, shorts, baseball caps or torn clothes are permissible. The Dinner Detective reserves the right to refuse entry to any guests whose dress does not conform to our dress code.

Tickets must be purchased on the website. Prices are $76.60 per person. When filling out the information, there is a section where you can enter my last name to get a table with me (so enter "Blanco"). There is also a section where you can specify which entree you want. It is confusing, I know, I just selected 1 for steak.

Parking is at the Holiday Inn and is free. We can either meet at the check-in or at the table we'll be sitting at (tables are all assigned).
results.how_to_find_us: At check-in, or at our table that is assigned.

results.description:
This is a joint event with the Cards & Conversations meetup group so we don't have a waitlist. Tonight is an open game night -- all card, tile, board and party games are welcome. Be sure to bring your favorite one :) If you rsvp "yes" and then have a change of plans please be sure to update your rsvp ahead of time so that you won't be counted as a "no show" and to allow for other members to attend since we have a limit on attendance. Thank you very much.

Live in the Metrowest area and want to come to our events but they're too far away? Want to make some new friends, eat some good food and play some fun games in the process? Make some time on your calendar for Saturday night because we have the event just for you.

While all games are welcome, here are some suggestions for tonight:

American Mah Jongg -- whether you are a beginner or a seasoned pro, we guarantee that there will be a table (or two) for people to play and mingle.

Cribbage -- a lot of people are picking up this game, because it is so awesome. Do you have a cribbage board? If so, be sure to bring it :)

Sequence -- Have you played this game before? The rules are simple but I warn you that it is quite addicting.

We'll be meeting at the Panera in Waltham. Panera offers an inviting setting to meet friends for a light meal and conversation. The bakery-cafe offers innovative salads and sandwiches, delicious baked goods and healthy frozen shakes.

WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW

This event is free, but please support the group and the event location by purchasing a drink or meal while you are Panera. The food is very good, so it will be hard to resist!

Please do not bring outside food or drinks into Panera.

Note that due to limited space we may place a limit on attendees if too many people sign up (or cancel it if we don't get any at all!)

HOW TO GET THERE

Panera Bread is located at 1100 Lexington Street in Waltham -- in the Shaw's plaza near the corner of Lexington Street and Trapelo Road. Ample parking. Web site: http://www.panera-bos...
results.name: Fun & Games in Waltham, MA

results.description:
Reservations are required through llbean.com/Burlington in order to attend.
Discover the beauty of nature at night as you paddle through calm waters under the glow of the summer moon. We believe a full moon enhances the beauty of these secluded waters and creates a truly memorable adventure. On this leisurely excursion, you'll paddle comfortable, stable kayaks and get a chance to experience nature up close. After a short paddling demonstration, your experienced guide will lead you on a revealing tour, sharing interesting facts about the area's history and the surrounding landscape. As the moon rises higher in the sky, you'll start to see the fascinating wildlife that emerges when the sun sets.

This spectacular tour only occurs during the weeks of the full moon and is a special adventure you won't want to miss. No prior kayaking experience is needed. All necessary paddling equipment is provided.

Price is $59 per person.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the green Outdoor Discovery School trailer in the parking lot of the Lakeside Hotel at 595 North Ave in Wakefield MA
results.name: Full Moon Kayak Tour

results.description:
Full Moon Gong: with Dharam Singh, Guruatma Kaur, and Siri Tapa Kaur

New Moon Gong: with Guruatma Kaur

 What to expect: Preparing ourselves with a Kundalini Yoga set we will create a body-mind balance for change and healing. While in this state the sound waves of the gong and bowls induce an extended state of effortless meditation and relaxation that facilitates the movement of prana through the body and psyche for healing. In this way, the gong is a tool that magnifies and focuses the power of the yoga experience.   


We will finish with tea, treats, and joy! 

Please bring a thick blanket or cushion to lie on and a shawl to cover with!   

“The Gong is the first and last instrument for the human mind, there is only one thing that can supersede and command the human mind, the sound of the Gong. It is the first sound in the Universe, the sound that created the Universe. It’s the basic creative sound. To the mind, the sound of the gong is like a mother and father that gave it birth. The mind has no power to resist a gong that is well played.”  -Yogi Bhajan, Master of Kundalini Yoga   

Yoga & Gong: Guruatma Kaur: An IKYTA certified teacher and devoted student of Yogi Bhajan, Guruatma Kaur has been enthusiastically teaching Kundalini Yoga since 1979. She is lovingly dedicated to encouraging clarity, excellence, and relaxation into one’s True Self.  

Gong:  Dharam Singh began an exploration of sound as a saxophonist and flutist in the Bronx, NYC - an environment immersed in the rich music and culture of Africa by way of the Caribbean, Boriqua, African American and the counter culture, which gave him a multicultural perspective on musical language.   His passion for the transformative power of sound and music has found a place in the use of the Gong as he came to develop a unifying aural language that removes the separation between Head and Heart, Body and Soul. It is these frequencies, tones and harmonics, already given by Nature that he simply lives to share.  Dharam is a long time student of Yogi Bhajan and a resident of Guru Ram Das Ashram, where he is the go-to guy for anything related to Gong Yoga, including buying one - www.gongsongs.com He is part of the 'three-some' that leads the monthly Full Moon Gong event 

Meditation: Siri Tapa Kaur, a Reiki Master, Sat Nam Rasayan Practitioner, and certified Kundalini Yoga Teacher lives a life committed to being healthy, happy, and available to all. Everyone who knows her is touched by her open-hearted, compassionate mother energy. 

Note: in case of any date discrepancy between this Meetup and the website, please believe the website!
results.how_to_find_us: Yoga at the Ashram is located at the Baba Siri Chand Yoga Center at Guru Ram Das Ashram, 368 Village St in Millis, MA 02054
results.name: Full and New Moon Yoga, Gongs, and Meditation

results.description:
THIS IS A ORGANIZED, HOSTED EVENT THAT BEGINS AT 7:00PM.  IF YOU CANNOT MEET AT 7:00PM DO NOT SIGN UP.

Hi,

Let's enjoy a beautiful summer evening by the water listening to music!  Lenny Kravitz is performing this Saturday at the Blue Hills Bank Pavilion in the Seaport district.  I guess he's fallen out of popularity because the venue is only half sold.


I've run a few events at this venue in the past and they've been so much fun.  We'll meet by the box office and buy our tickets together and pay separately.  There's plenty of food and drink options which can be a little pricey so you might want to fill up beforehand.  Andra Day is the opening act and then Lenny takes the stage.  The show should be over by 11:00pm for those of you taking public transportation.

I have shut off the "guest" feature.  If you have to bring someone, please have them join Social Fun and sign up separately.


If you have any questions, let me know.

Hope to see you there!

Dee
results.name: Lenny Kravitz in concert!

results.description:
Enjoy a leisurely moonlight paddle on the lake with like-hearted others. Perhaps we'll visit the beaver lodges, maybe even see one going about its nocturnal busyness, or hear one slap its tail in warning. We'll quietly explore the lake, as we enjoy the evening air, the night sounds and the moonlight glimmering across the water. Then we'll return to shore, light the fire pit and enjoy toasted marshmallows and fine conversation.
We have canoes/kayak for eleven. You are also welcome to bring your own.
We look forward to celebrating each full moon throughout the summer this way.
$10 suggested donation.
results.how_to_find_us: Alllow extra time to find us the first time. Call to be guided in 978-579-0897. Look for beige two-story three-car garage on the left. Park in driveway, anywhere except in front of garage doors. Walk around to the left side of the house to our door.
results.name: Inspiring Life: Moonlight Canoe/kayak and campfire

results.description:
Backroads ride to Northampton.  

Ok group....   Here's the plan for Saturday 8/29/15.

This ride, as Cindy prefaced before, is going to be a long day with many miles...  This will be give or take a 450 mile day!

We will leave "promptly" at 8:30 am. from Randolph and plan to have everyone home by dark, which is getting much earlier these days.    I anticipate 90% back roads, but as you all know, depending on timing, this is always subject to change.   I will of course make a couple of gas stops, but don't plan for any other stops on the way.  I want to give us a couple of hours to play downtown Northampton before heading back home.  There is so much to do and see in this town.  

All the local colleges should be in full swing by Saturday, so it may be a bit crowded.  We will find suitable parking when we get there.

We don't have a formal lunch plan for this ride, so you may either pack a "saddlebag" lunch or eat at one of the many eateries downtown, your choice!

See you Saturday!

Road Captain:  Deeg  "Thunder heart"
results.name: Naughty Northampton

results.description:
Do you wanna know what was named Boston A-List's Best Night of Comedy? THEN COME ON DOWN TO THE MENDOZA LINE TO FIND OUT WHY!

This and every Saturday night live from the back room of the The Dugout Cafe (722 Comm Ave), Jenny Chalikian, John Baglio, Julia Claire, and Zach "Zack" Armentrout bring you the biggest baddest bestiest comedians from Boston and beyond. And guess what? Its only FIVE DOLLARS. With drink specials as far as the eye can see and free popcorn, this intimate atmosphere is the perfect place to take in some meaningful laughs.

This week is a very special episode: our dear friend, Jenny Chalikian, moving to the greener pastures of Los Angeles, California. Jenny has been a co-producer of this show since February, and has been a delight to work with and we wish her all the best. Come out to see her before she leaves us forever!

Also featuring the comedic talents of:

SAURIN CHOKSI (Boston Comedy Festival winner, host of White Guy Talk Show on Fuse)

KRISTIN SELTMAN (Women in Comedy Festival)

NICK CHAMBERS (Comedy Studio Comic in Residence 2014)

PETER BANACHOWSKI (visiting from LA, has opened for Amy Schumer and Aziz Ansari)

MARK GALLAGHER (Star)

ALISON KLEMP (Brooklyn Comedy Festival, I'm Fine Probably)

and

DOUG KEY (Rogue Island Comedy Festival)

Buy your tix now to guarantee a seat as spaces are limited. We don't want to turn you away again, Hank!

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-mendoza-line-bostons-best-weekly-comedy-showcase-tickets-15228587114
results.name: The Mendoza Line! $5 Comedy Every Saturday!

results.description:
We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/
results.name: Couch to 5K Autumn Edition

results.description:
What better way to celebrate summer than by greeting the day with an hour of yoga in the sunshine?

Every Sunday this summer from July 12 through August 30, Coolidge Corner Yoga and The Brookline Departments of Health and Parks and Open Space will be co-hosting a free all-levels Vinyasa flow at Minot Rose Park in front of its beautiful rose garden. Don’t miss out on this chance to practice with your favorite CCY teachers, bond with Brookline community members, and enjoy the opportunity to practice yoga in the great outdoors. Wear comfy clothes, bring a bottle of water, and come prepared to start your weekend with movement and fun!
results.name: Free Outdoor Yoga at Minot Rose Park

results.description:
Maine Sail Freight Invites You!  Come celebrate dockside with events and speakers! See the caravan of Metro Pedal Power’s cherry red bike trailers ferrying food to the Boston Public market.  We’ve decked out the Pavillion to welcome you.  Boat is docked off the tip of  Long Wharf, look on your map for the  Compass Rose near Boston Aquarium.

Sunrise, hot tea!

8 am – noon : UNLOADING!

Join the stevedores unloading cargo into the Pavillion, and then onto cherry red bike courier trailers.

12 noon Sales begin of MAINE goods delivered via sail right there at the Long Wharf

Events & Performances (12 noon – 7pm)

Long Wharf Pavillion of Commons, meet organizations engaged in enlivenment.  Pavillion of tablers includes Slow Money, Slow Food, Mass Horticulture, Metro Pedal Power, Crown of Maine Coop, and others..

12 noon- 2pm: Tours of historic Maine schooner Harvey Gamage

1pm Brian Dewan sings “Songs of Land & Sea”

3.00- 3.30 pm: Sea shanties with Revels Legend David Coffin

4 pm: “Commons of Land and Sea: seaweed and community fisheries in a changing climate”

Niaz Dory—–Pierre Belanger—- Marada Cook 

Pierre Bélanger is Associate Professor of Landscape Architecture and Co-Director of the MDes Postgraduate Design Research Program at Harvard University’s Graduate School of Design. Cross-appointed with the Department of Landscape Architecture and the Advanced Studies Program, Bélanger teaches and coordinates graduate courses on the convergence of ecology, infrastructure, media and urbanism in the interrelated fields of design, communications, planning and engineering.  In response to the inertia of urban planning and the overexertion of civil engineering in public works today, Bélanger’s contribution to the field of “landscape infrastructure” has been shared and developed in collaboration with governments, professionals and academics worldwide. Vis-à-vis the complexities, magnitudes and indeterminacies of urban change, Bélanger’s core commitment lies in the agency of landscape architecture to redefine the morphology of urban infrastructure in research, pedagogy and practice.

Niaz Dory is the coordinating director of the Northwest Atlantic Marine Alliance (NAMA). For the past 20 years, Niaz has been working on advancing the rights and ecological benefits of the small-scale fishing communities as a means of protecting global marine biodiversity. NAMA works with small and medium scale fishermen on policy alternatives and market transformation strategies that support traditional fishing communities to have the smallest ecological footprint and the biggest food system, economic and social impact. In winter 2007/2008, NAMA and the Port Clyde, Maine community pioneered the Community Supported Fishery (CSF) model, which has since grown to 50 + across the Americas and Europe through the localcatch.org network. Before joining NAMA, Niaz served as the Interim Chief Operations Office for the Healthy Building Network, and began working with small-scale, traditional, and indigenous fishing communities in the U.S. and from around the globe as a Greenpeace oceans and fisheries campaigner. Time Magazine named Niaz as a Hero For The Planet for this work. Her fisheries articles appear regularly in Fishermen’s Voice and SAMUDRA as well as a range of random publications. Niaz’ work and approach have been noted in a number of books including Against the Tide, Deeper Shade of Green, The Spirit’s Terrain, Vanishing Species, The Great Gulf, Swimming in Circles, A Troublemaker’s Teaparty and The Doryman’s Reflection. She is a graduate of the Rockwood Leadership Program’s Leading From Inside Out as well as Art of Leadership trainings. She serves on the executive committee of the National Family Farm Coalition and Granite State Fish, as well as on the core team of Food Solutions New England. She recently served as an advisor to the Harvard Medical School’s Center for Health and Global Environment.

Marada Cook and Leah Cook, Owners of Crown O’ Maine Organic Cooperative. This cooperative provides distribution services to farms in Maine, delivering local and organic food to food stores, institutions, restaurants, and buyers clubs. Their innovative distribution model has helped realize their goal of improving access to locally grown products in Maine. Leah and Marada also both own Northern Girl and Fiddlers Green Farm.

http://www.fiddlersgreenmaine.com/maine-freight-sail-boxes/


Monday August 31 // Central Square Market 12-6pm 

6.45 pm MAINE SAIL// DINNER Sea salt, Oats+ Seaweed themes at Cuisine EN Locale, 156 Highland Ave, Somerville, MA 02143, a former Italian social club and current Grange-like community center, restaurant, music venue and glorious pin-ball/pool table mixology den.

Hosted exemplars of local purchasing will feature some sail-delivered foods from Maine. A rum-roundtable  improvides dinner-time conversation on the Regional Food Economy with Marada Cook, Severine v T Fleming, JJ Gonson, Wenzday  Jane.  Join us for the dinner and conversation, you can book ahead at (617)[masked] info here: http://cuisineenlocale.com

Tuesday September 1 // Farmers Market- Cambridge, Harvard @Science Center 12-6 pm in partnership with Club Passim.

6.30pm Eliza Greenman on “Heritage apples, Quakers and the underground railroad.”

Wednesday September 2 // Boston Public Market, selling from the stall!  8am- 8pm

6pm – 8pm Brian Donahue+John Foti at BOSTON PUBLIC MARKET

Trade, Commons, Seedstock and revolutionary politics.

*(Suggested $10  donation for all evening programs)

Full month of September:

Visit the restaurant TRADE, to enjoy a featured set of Maine Sail ingredients in the already impeccably sourced menu of restauranteur Jodi Adams.  As young farmers, we commend chefs like her who exemplify a commitment  to supporting new producers that continue to diversify the offerings from this region. Thank you for helping to launch the small businesses of food sovereignty!

LOCATION: 540 Atlantic Ave, Boston, MA 02210 CONTACT:(617)[masked]

Learn more about ethical chefs: www.chefscollaborative.org

results.description:
Hello all, 

Let's continue WTR's traditional quadrathlon with III. Annual Quadrathlon this year! The plan is to meet at Waltham Commuter Rail parking lot, bike to Walden Pond, swim and run the lake and bike back. We will take a break at Dairy Joy on the way back for some ice cream. 

This event is for fun. You do not have to complete the whole course, so feel free to join us for a single event or for the whole thing. 

Be active, social and have fun! 

Based on the previous years data, here is the plan:

8:35 - Leave Waltham on bike
9:20 - Arrive to Walden Pond, after 8.5 miles of biking
9:30 - Swim 
10:30 - Run
11:15 - Finish the run.
11:45 - Diary Joy! (~6 miles from Walden Pond) Thanks everyone for a very fun day!
results.name: Quadrathlon (Bike, Swim, Run, Eat Ice Cream)

venue.name: Quincy Market - Faneuil Hall Marketplace

results.description:
“Great photography is about depth of feeling, not depth of field.”
– Peter Adams


Greetings Photographers! The weather for Sunday looks great so let's go first thing in the morning. We will start at Quincy Market, then head to the waterfront and end up at the North End where you can catch some of St. Anthonys Feast. 

There you can join the parade, have some pastries from Mikes or enjoy some great Italian Sausage Sandwiches from the street vendors. Best of all there will be plenty of fascinating subjects for you to practice your street photography after we warm up our skills in the other two locations. 

Many of you have been asking for a class on how to photograph people. And some of you have been avoiding this topic.(You know who you are.) This is your chance to learn the secrets of how to creatively photograph total strangers on the street. 

Marching Band getting ready for the North End Feast last year. Telling me to watch that camera angle. No shooting from the ground up. 

Photographing people, strangers, friends, family, is a skill we should all strive to develop. It is a wonderful part of being a photographer, to be able to capture moment of beauty as people enjoy the simple pleasures of life. I hope you will join us to hone your skill. 


This special workshop on street photography will introduce you to a step by step method for gaining confidence in photographing people. This is a essential skill for travel photographers, family photographers, and anyone interested in capturing the ordinary moments of life in a way that tells a story.

Quincy Market birds eye view. Creative angle on street photography.

We will start at Quincy Market where there are plenty of people to practice on.  People will be busy shopping, eating, and watching street performers so they will never notice you are photographing them for your class assignments.

Waiting for a cookie. Photo by Suzanne Use of 1/3 2/3 composition and catching the light.

Some of the topics I will cover in the workshop will be:

• Timing and positioning so you increase the chances of getting the lucky shot.

• Composition of subjects within the frame and in relationship to each other.

• How to use elements of color, light, texture, and motion to evoke emotion and tell a story. 

• How to simplify the shot so you capture the essence of the moment.


• Some basic camera operation tips will be offered if you need them.


Mid Air Action Photo by workshop participant. Good diagonal  composition and attention to uncluttered background selection.

How we will work:

We will meet together in front of the Faneuil Hall building at Quincy Market where I will give a short introduction to the topics and show you sample photos. You will be given specific photo assignments designed to build your skills step by step. I will provide handout cards so you can practice the assignments again after the class.

We will be shooting people in three different city settings so please wear comfortable shoes and pack lightly so you can be on the move. 

After class there will be social time where we will take a look at the photos of the day and give each other constructive critique. I highly recommend you plan on joining us for this part of the workshop. We will find a spot for "refreshments" near the third assignment location. 

Photo by participant Guy Lafontaine during recent Photographing strangers workshop. Strong composition crop in close and fill the frame with the subject. 

Please RSVP right away to hold your spot in this class. The tuition for the workshop is $30.00 I look forward to seeing you on Sunday.

P.S. This class is appropriate for all levels so if you have just joined the group, this would be a perfect place to start. You will meet like minded people who love photography and you will learn some new skills at the same time. What a great way to spend the morning.

Until we meetup,

Suzanne

Spending time together. First assignment will be in Quincy Market.

Location of our second assignment, down by the waterfront. 

Third assignment will be in the North End at the Feast.

results.description:
This venue honors Charles River Boating as well as Boating in Boston season passes.  Some may have purchased groupons or living social coupons for either of these places.

We'll paddle the waters of Boston Harbor at Carson Beach which can be reached by Red Line or car. Please bring cash. We'll learn the basics on shore then plan to put them in the water for 1 to 1.5 hour which is plenty of time for a workout and to learn all you need to know. If you already know how to kayak, you are welcome to join us too.   


After we kayak, we can relax on the beach, walk.  Also, there is a fast take-out place at Castle Island (about a 25-30 minute walk) where you can get food and  or ice cream).  Food served at a reasonable price include hot dogs, hamburgers, fish, fries, onion rings...  There are bathrooms/changing areas available on the beach.

Park in the Carson Beach Lot or on Babe Ruth Avenue or take the Red Line (best way) to JFK and walk 9 minutes to McCormick Bathhouse, Carson Beach, South Boston. 


If there is a wait for kayaks, some will start kayaking while others watch from the beach or walk Castle Island. Then, the second group will go out while the first group watches or walks.  

Single kayaks are $15/hour; tandems are  $20.  We may have to take tandems if there are no more singles available.

If you have any questions,  can post in comment section.

Kayaking is easier than canoeing and much safer than it has been in the past. Wearing a rubber skirt and rolling the kayak is no longer required.
http://boatinginboston.com/

We'll meet at these tables (see photo above) which is across from Boating in Boston where we rent kayaks in the brick building below (McCormick Bathhouse). 


Carson Beach

This sandy beach, owned and maintained by the Commonwealth's Department of Conservation and Recreation, is one of the best swimming beaches in the area, with nearby public amenities and great views of the Harbor. New sand, new walkways, benches, lighting, shade shelters and award winning landscaping have helped to make Carson Beach a popular destination. The recently renovated Edward J. McCormack Bathhouse, one of the first facilities completed as part of the "Back to the Beaches" effort, has restrooms, changing rooms, showers, drinking water fountains, chess tables, and bocce courts. In addition, it hosts first aid and lifeguard functions. "Mother's Rest" and its fishing pier have also been rehabilitated, making for a beautiful picnic area with a fantastic view of the Harbor.

HOW TO KAYAK


STEP 1 Gear up

Choose a kayak suited for learning. A sit-on-top model is best for beginners and what we'll be using. Wear a life jacket.

STEP 2 Get in


Step into the kayak, crouching to keep your center of gravity low, and quickly sit down. On a beach, lay the paddle across the cockpit and rest one end on the sand to steady the boat as you get in.

Lean back comfortably in the seat as you paddle. This will help the boat stay stable.

STEP 3 Paddle

Hold the paddle with an overhand grip, thumbs under, and dip one side into the water. Pull down and back with one hand while pushing forward with the other hand. Dip the paddle straight in and pull it back even with your hips. Then dip the other side.

Paddle with a smooth, rhythmic motion. Use your torso muscles and sit up straight without leaning into your strokes.

STEP 4 Turn

Paddle on only one side to turn the kayak in an opposite direction. Or use the paddle like a rudder, dragging it on the side you want to turn toward.

STEP 5 Practice falling out or turning the kayak over in water

Strap the paddle to a kayak, then grab the middle of the kayak. Kick to pull yourself onto a sit-on model, which are the easy ones we'll be using.

STEP 6 Watch conditions

Be aware of water and weather conditions. Paddle at an angle to the wind until you're near the shore before continuing.

STEP 7 Know the rules and your limits

Learn the rules that determine right-of-way on the water. Give the right of way to less maneuverable watercraft.

STEP 8 Get out.

Use your balance and take your time.

Remember: Your Event Organizers are volunteers. You are responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. results.description:
I've always wanted to experience a Cacao Ceremony, and they are having one in Salem! This is also posted in the Evolving Beings Meetup. Price: $30

Chocolate! One of the greatest medicines on the planet! When ceremoniously consuming cacao, it creates an open heart and the sensation of falling in love. Sit in silent meditation if you want, dance away stress, stretch and expand yourself! Cacao is a super food; especially beneficial for the heart and brain. The ceremony begins with setting your intention. As the Cacao takes effect, you will be soaking in some sounds of the hoop drum, chanting, the didgeridoo and the singling bowl. Then you are invited to play instruments, dance, meditate, converse with new friends, draw, or just absorb the energy. The heart opening effects last one-four hours! Eat a light meal before the ceremony, and drink lots of water during and after the ceremony. This event takes place the morning after the full moon...so we can also bask in full moon energy.
results.name: Experience a Cacao Ceremony!

results.description:
This is NOT flat terrain.

Meeting at outside the Visitor Center (at picnic table). Please arrive 15 minutes early. We start hiking on time; plan your travel accordingly. 

The Hike:

We will be hiking (2 hours, including a break at the top) the western section of the sanctuary to the summit Bluff Hill, then retrace our steps back. Good views to the west and south await us on Bluff Hill. The hike will be at a moderate pace over uneven rocky terrain with elevation gain.

There is a trail fee. Mass Audubon Members enjoy FREE admission. $4 for nonmember adults.

info about the park: http://www.massaudubon.org/get-outdoors/wildlife-sanctuaries/moose-hill

online trial map: http://www.massaudubon.org/content/download/8080/145429/file/moosehill_trails.pdf

After Hike, Food and Drinks:

After the hike, we will gather for food and drinks. Some options for the after hike event are:

* Mick Morgan, 973 Providence Hwy, Walpole, MA.

RSVP Responsibility! 

Only RSVP if you can go and update your RSVP (don't wait until the day of the event) if you can't make it.

I am only a volunteer. I will be waiting at the trail starting point, and I will be expecting you. I look forward to meeting you.

* No pets allowed on hike.

* Members only. No guests permitted.

* Members must have a valid photo.

Gear and Dress:

* Bring minimum of one liter of water. 

* Hiking boots suggested.

* Dress appropriately for the weather conditions. 

* Non-cotton clothing works best.  

* Bring water, snacks and any personal medicines and gear you may need as well.

FOUL WEATHER CANCELS.

You assume all risk associated with this activity.

Liability Waiver: As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at <a>www.hikesafe.com;</a> the leader(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify the leader(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

Directions to Hike:

From the north: Take Rt I-95 south to exit 10 (Coney St, Sharon, Walpole). Take a left off the exit and take the first right onto Rt 27 north (Walpole). Take first left on Moose Hill Street. Continue past The Trustees of Reservations (TTOR) Moose Hill Farm. Follow to the top of the hill and turn left onto Moose Hill Parkway. The parking lot is on the left.

From the south: Take Rt I-95 north to exit 8 (Main St, Sharon). Take a right off the exit and follow one mile. Take a left onto Moose Hill Street. Follow to the top of the hill and turn right onto Moose Hill Parkway. The parking lot is on the left.
results.name: Moose Hill Hike then Lunch

results.description:
This is NOT flat terrain.


Meeting at outside the Visitor Center (at picnic table). Please arrive 15 minutes early. We start hiking on time; plan your travel accordingly.


The Hike:

We will be hiking (2 hours, including a break at the top) the western section of the sanctuary to the summit Bluff Hill, then retrace our steps back. Good views to the west and south await us on Bluff Hill. The hike will be at a moderate pace over uneven rocky terrain with elevation gain.

There is a trail fee. Mass Audubon Members enjoy FREE admission. $4 for nonmember adults.

info about the park: http://www.massaudubon.org/get-outdoors/wildlife-sanctuaries/moose-hill

online trial map: http://www.massaudubon.org/content/download/8080/145429/file/moosehill_trails.pdf

After Hike, Food and Drinks:

After the hike, we will gather for food and drinks. Some options for the after hike event are:

* Mick Morgan, 973 Providence Hwy, Walpole, MA

RSVP Responsibility!


Only RSVP if you can go and update your RSVP (don't wait until the day of the event) if you can't make it.

I am only a volunteer. I will be waiting at the trail starting point, and I will be expecting you. I look forward to meeting you.

* No pets allowed on hike.

* Members only. No guests permitted.

* Members must have a valid photo.

Gear and Dress:

* Bring minimum of one liter of water. 

* Hiking boots suggested.


* Dress appropriately for the weather conditions.


* Non-cotton clothing works best.  


* Bring water, snacks and any personal medicines and gear you may need as well.

FOUL WEATHER CANCELS.

You assume all risk associated with this activity.

Liability Waiver: As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at <a>www.hikesafe.com;</a> the leader(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify the leader(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.


Directions to Hike:

From the north: Take Rt I-95 south to exit 10 (Coney St, Sharon, Walpole). Take a left off the exit and take the first right onto Rt 27 north (Walpole). Take first left on Moose Hill Street. Continue past The Trustees of Reservations (TTOR) Moose Hill Farm. Follow to the top of the hill and turn left onto Moose Hill Parkway. The parking lot is on the left.

From the south: Take Rt I-95 north to exit 8 (Main St, Sharon). Take a right off the exit and follow one mile. Take a left onto Moose Hill Street. Follow to the top of the hill and turn right onto Moose Hill Parkway. The parking lot is on the left.
results.name: Moose Hill Hike then Lunch

results.description:
Sunday, August 30th, 11am – 7pm  (with a short lunch break, not provided)

This will be an all day, intensive introduction to WICCAN spirituality.

Our focus will be twofold:

First, we will learn about the history of "Wicca" the modern Pagan movement, and separating fact from fiction.  It's roots in pre-historic folk magic and spirituality, the influences of ancient esoteric knowledge, ceremonial magic and yes, that Gardner guy.

Second, we will learn the metaphysical principles of magic, ritual structure, use of tools and symbols and begin to develop our own personal connection with the divine.  

We will use lecture, discussion, guided visualization, and conclude the evening with a ritual mini-dedication to honor everyone’s continued learning and growth.

This class is by pre-registration only.  There is a fee of $30 for each attendee (if cost is prohibitive please contact your organizer for scholarships).

This class will be great for beginners and for those who want to further explore the roots of the modern Pagan movement.  Come prepared to learn a lot!  Share a lot! And enjoy learning about the Wiccan spiritual path!

Sponsored by Cornucopia Collective: dedicated to building a fruitful Pagan community together!

results.description:
Our services have three parts: Healing Service, a Lecture on a spiritual topic, and Mediumship Spirit Communication. Each part lasts approximately 30 minutes.

The Healing Service gives you the opportunity to receive healing energy that is channeled through one of our Healers. We believe that healing can be channeled through thought to those who need it. This is a very calming experience, whether or not you choose to sit in a healing chair.  We encourage you to send healing to your loved ones, our communities, and Mother Earth.

The Lecture covers a variety of topics ranging from the History of Spiritualism to Inspired Insights. It also includes examples of how Spiritualism is a part of our lives on a daily basis.

Mediumship, or Spirit Communication, is the part of the service where a medium proves that "...the existence and personal identity of the individual continue after the change called death." The medium might be a member of our church or visiting from another the Spiritualist church in the community. We also have mediums from abroad stop in often. While there is only enough time during a service for a few people to receive messages from their deceased loved ones on the Higher side Side of Life, everyone present benefits by witnessing proof of the continuation of life.

At the conclusion of the service everyone is invited to our social hour downstairs for coffee and conversation.﻿

results.description:
This session we will focus on Flow and speed. We will be creating cohesive paths from point a to b with focus on transitioning from skill to skill and making each run as efficient as possible. 


What if I've never done anything like Parkour before? 

This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun


http://www.projectfreerun.com/
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be on the main courtyard up the stairs. The location itself is of concrete construction, and has yellow rails!
results.name: -- Adults -- [Boston] Parkour 101 - Introduction to Parkour // Flow + Speed

results.description:
We have rented 3 badminton courts at the BU Fitness & Recreation Center (regulation full sized courts).  The BU facility is immaculate and a fantastic place to play.


The fee (payable online when you RSVP) gets you into the BU Fitness & Recreation Center to play badminton for an hour and a half.  Part of the fee is for the court time and the rest is for your meetup group to cover other expenses, i.e. rackets, shuttlecocks/birdies, meetup.com fees. All fees collected go to pay the Group's expenses.

We have rackets and shuttles for everyone!

Expect to play doubles. The host can help to match up pairs but members are free to join in any game they want.  The courts are reserved only for Boston Badminton members.

Before asking a question, please read through the following FAQs:

Q: The meetup is full, can I come regardless and pay at the event?
A: No, there is limited space to make sure everyone gets to play. A few spots typically open up before the event.

Q: It's my first time, how do I find you?
A: Go to the BU Fitness & Recreation Center reception (see directions below), and tell them you're here with Boston Badminton. They'll tell you where the courts are, check you're on the list, and make you sign a waiver. The meeting point is on the courts.

Q: I am a BU student, do I get a discount?
A: No, BU charges us the same regardless of whether participants are at BU or not.


Directions:
Please click here for a google map to The BU Fitness & Recreation Center.  The easiest way to get to the FitRec center from within Boston is to take the Green Line (B)-Boston College to Saint Paul St.  Parking is limited but available.  Please click here for parking information.

Plan to grab a drink locally after if we have interest.

The club has full locker room and shower facilities.

Note: In addition to agreeing to the Meetup's Liability Waiver, all members must sign a Waiver of Liability Form in order to use BU's courts. This form is available at the front desk at the FitRec center.  We may ask you for your full name in order to help BU and the meetup comply with the liability procedures.

Let me know if you have any questions and I hope to see you there!

The purpose of the following Liability Waiver is to protect Boston Badminton meetup members and group leaders from liability in case of accident or injury. All members must agree to the Liability Waiver in order to participate in the group and its activities.

In consideration of the opportunity to participate in events, activities, classes, and programs conducted by Boston Badminton and its affiliates in any venue, and to use equipment located therein, I, on behalf of myself and my minor children, do hereby release, hold harmless and forever discharge and agree not to sue Boston Badminton and its trustees, officers, agents, founders, members, volunteers and employees (together, "Meetup.com Group") from any and all claims, responsibilities or liabilities for injury or damages resulting from or arising out of my or my family’s use of, presence in, or participation in activities conducted at any venue rented or owned by Boston Badminton, whether or not caused by the ordinary negligence of Boston Badminton. I understand, recognize and acknowledge that certain activities conducted by Boston Badminton or taking place in venues rented or owned by Boston Badminton are potentially hazardous. I also acknowledge that it is my responsibility to follow instructions for any activity or use of equipment, and to seek help from the volunteers if I have any questions. I further understand that, notwithstanding precautions taken by Boston Badminton, sports and fitness activities involve a risk of injury and/or death. I/we are voluntarily participating in these activities and using equipment and machinery with knowledge of the dangers involved. *I'm repeating this meetup location for the benefit of good weather and because I heard the pastries were so good :D*

This is the repeat of a neighborhood sketch series where we will skip the monuments in favor of the "grain" of the city. 

Beacon Hill is a very recognizable and characterful neighborhood, climbing up from the commons, and dropping back down towards the Charles. Hills can create special challenges for drawing perspective as well.

<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t3jdEMxrNw4"></a>

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t3jdEMxrNw4


note how the hill has a different vanishing point than the rest of the perspective. 

We will meet at 2pm in front of the Church-like building at 70 Charles St. There is an excellent cafe inside. Then we will walk up the hill into the neighborhood and disperse. We will reconvene at 4pm at the cafe's outdoor seating to share our work and chat.

Looking forward to another great sketching session! Hope to see you there.

results.description:
(Instructions for Relay Go below.)

Hello!

This continues to be tons of fun, so we're going to go another round!

We have plenty of boards and stone, no need to bring your own.

We have water, tea, beer, etc. We will coordinate dinner in the evening.

There is also a convenience store right up the street and a ton of restaurants in the area to satisfy any miscellaneous snacking needs. Any brought snacks are appreciated!

Getting here / the place

We are about a 15 minute walk from the Davis Square t-station. There is parking on the street, which is free on Sundays and usually open. There is also a bus stop for 87, 88, and 89 about 3 minutes away.

We have a safe place to store bikes.

Full disclosure: We have 3 cats, just in case you are allergic or adverse!


Contact

Feel free to get a hold of me at [masked] or give me a call / text at[masked]

--

Here are the rules for Relay Go, as interpreted by Andy Okun:


"1. The game.


For those of you who aren't familiar with it, Team Relay Go works like this.  There are two teams, each with nine players and a coach.


In the first phase, 72 moves long, two of the players from each team begin to play pair go against each other, constrained from communicating with each other or anyone else.  The game is broadcast via Internet on one of the servers.  The rest of each team plus coach watch the game in a separate room or secluded area, where they may discuss the game among themselves.


They may not consult outsiders or use printed or computer assistance.


The coach may call a time out, limited I believe to two per match, in which he can discuss moves with his currently active players for 90 seconds.  He may also make a substitution, putting in a new player for one of the active players, once per phase of the game.


At the end of the first phase, two new players from each team take over from the old players, and continue the pair go game for another72 moves, with the same restrictions, time out and substitution opportunities.

After the end of the second phase of 72 moves, a third pair from each team take over, and complete the game, with the same substitution, time out and restricted communication.  The teams have a conventional time limit, with main time of (if I recall correctly) an hour, and byo yomi style overtime."

We may be playing with smaller teams, depending on attendance.

results.description:
Welcome to the fantastic kingdom of fungi. In this fascinating workshop you learn how to grow edible mushrooms in your own backyard!

The workshop will cover techniques for growing mushrooms on logs, totems, stumps, and wood chip beds. Willie will discuss methods of finding and preparing materials for inoculation, different methods and tools used for inoculation. After the demonstration, everyone will get to dig into their own log! All participants will go home with an inoculated log ready to fruit mushrooms. Willie Crosby has been studying and growing fungi for the past four years. He started Fungi Ally, a mushroom cultivation and education business based out of Amherst MA. Currently, Willie grows about 100 pounds of shiitakes and oysters a week. He studied with Aloha Medicinals two years ago learning aspects of indoor cultivation and lab technique. Willie has taught over 50 workshops in Massachusetts and surrounding states on mushroom cultivation.
Light appetizers (mushroom themed!) will be served, bring a bottle of wine to share if you would like. Bring a folding chair for the demonstration.

Join KCG at the this FUNdraiser to bring healthy eating and cooking to all. The cost of the event is $65 for one person, or $100 for two.


Please consider making a further donation to Kids Cooking Green to support programming for underserved communities. Visit our Fund for City Schools page to check out some of our new programs. CLICK HERE TO REGISTER
http://events.r20.constantcontact.com/register/event?oeidk=a07eb5i8fo63b9985d4&llr=iw76p6iab

Questions?
Lori Deliso
Kids Cooking Green

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE: Tavern in the Square in Porter Square

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Look down the street. There's Tavern in the Square! If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Erika and Jack

results.description:
This is an ongoing weekly (donation only) class for anyone, offering experiential practice in meditation, along with an opportunity to be among others interested in deepening spiritutual practices.  The class provides you with a felt sense of your own divinity; your Higher Self. The meditation, based on Kriya practices,  is partly guided, partly silent. In the guided part we open up to the flow of golden light and energy that is always pouring down to our body/mind/heart and being. Accessing that flow and inviting it to fill us brings a profound level of openness, while washing away limiting thoughts, feelings and beliefs. This higher vibration of unconditional love serves to open our consciousness to new levels of peace, joy and awakening. Bringing the flow of light into the body/mind/heart means we more consciously embody our Light Being, so we are more present, happy, forgiving, peaceful and joyful while in the world.
   After the guided portion we spend time in peaceful silence.  Whether you are an experienced meditator or a beginner, you will love the sweetness and powerful energies of this group. At the end of the class we make time for questions or sharing.  Group meditation is powerful, and it's refreshing to be among fellow travelers!
   Judy also teaches the Sound and Light meditation; a way for you to draw your senses inward to open your spiritual eye and to hear the sounds of your chakras. 
   This practice is non-denominational, appropriate for anyone. 
   Held in a lovely healing space, just walking in will bring you instant peace.  All are welcome.
    You may also want to check out my other Meetup, for a variety of spiritual programs:  http://www.meetup.com/Evolving-Beings/

results.description:
Let's join 20+ others from six other walking groups for:

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.

Ushered into an isolated gray stone mansion on the windswept Cornish coast, the second Mrs. Maxim de Winter recalls the chilling events that transpired as she began her new life as the young bride of a husband she barely knew. For in every corner of every room were phantoms of a time dead but not forgotten—a past devotedly preserved by the sinister housekeeper, Mrs. Danvers: a suite immaculate and untouched, clothing laid out and ready to be worn, but not by any of the great house's current occupants...

Join me for this regular monthly Full Moon Labyrinth Walk at the Somerville Growing Center (just outside of Union Square). I offer this outdoor labyrinth walk gathering each month on the Sunday nearest the full moon - May through October.

We'll have a little introduction of walking for those new to labyrinths and some fun discussion about the moon's current astrology and energy we might tap into for reflection or inspiration.

After our contemplative walk, those who wish, may linger for more conversation, community and snacks !

** Note the time change for this one - we start at 6:30 instead of 7:00 (sadly our late day light is beginning to wane).
results.how_to_find_us: There's free parking on Vinal Ave. on Sundays. Also not far from the #87 bus along Somerville Ave.
results.name: Monthly Sunday Evening Full Moon Labyrinth Walk

results.description:
Growing up is overrated. You hear that a lot from adults, particularly those of us with healthy relationships with their inner child :) But somehow, someone is minding the store in their lives. So what are the hallmarks of maturity in this day in age? What does it mean to be a mature adult today vs 50 or 100 years ago?  Has technology made us less mature by taking away adversity and enabling instant gratification?  What effect, if any, has telecommunications had (TV, internet, phone vs letter writing skills)?  Cultural differences? Will the pendulum swing with future generations looking back at us calling us a bunch of whiny babies?  What does maturity mean to you, and (ahem, bold introspection) in what ways do you see it, or see it lacking, in yourself?

Join us for a "mature" (or not) discussion of what it means to be all growed up.

Hope to see you there :)
results.name: Modern Maturity

results.description:
Join us and a panel of guests for an in-depth discussion on some successful ways to create lasting networks that can grow - organically!

Andy Oram, a well read author from O'Reilly publishing who networks daily with writers and researchers.

Terra Friedrichs, a socially responsible business consultant assisting organizations in strategic planning, priority setting, decision making, project planning, and management, with a focus on measuring value not only in terms of dollars, but in terms of time and community value and life goals.

Jason Lowenthal, a political campaign outreach organizer, hosting local Boston4Bernie events and getting out the crowd!


Micky Metts, a person that networks as outreach for the Drupal community, the Free Software movement and Solidarity Economy.


Plus - a few cooperative members (worker-owners) will also share some tips on how they network to find projects and to grow their coop.

The panel of guests will talk about the ways they  have found to network that are successful. We will then relate these methods to how we use networking to find or build a cooperative business with like-minded people. The panel can also answer questions or pose tips to help us all break out of our regular mindset about networking and find ways to reach out to those that might have relevant info for you, and those that may need info you have -- without becoming a pest:) We will discuss how to cross pollinate and meet people out of your current network that may have similar goals. Advice will be given on trying new or different networking techniques and perhaps we will share some funny stories of networking gone awry:)

1. How to create campaigns that reach the right targets and send the right message.

2. How to keep up with cooperative news and events.

3. What type of events should you attend?

4. How to use skills you probably already have to network.

5. What tools are needed to network today?

6. How to help others network for you?

7. How do deadlines for print Advertising affect networking?

8. How do your colleagues help or foil your networking efforts... is it just bad communication skills, or lack of advance planning?

9. Networker or nuisance? How often do you contact a person?

10. Reviving a dead network.

The usual delicious potluck is welcome and Agaric will also provide some snacks and beverages. If you wish to be ON the panel as a guest, contact me - [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: @agaric
results.name: Networking your way into a cooperative and making it grow...

results.description:
From 6:30 to 7:30 PM, every Sunday evening, the BK Learning Center for Peace is open to everyone wanting to deepen their meditation experiences, filling the self with peace and power to develop spiritual capacity for the challenging week ahead.

Guidance and simple visual exercises that enable us to access our inner peace and strength will be offered during the meditation session.

 

All are welcome to attend and no RSVP is needed.

 

This is offered FREE OF CHARGE as a community service
results.name: Sunday Night Meditation

results.description:
Bring your instruments! Bring your friends! Let's play Bluegrass together!

There will be some refreshments present… feel free to bring your own or something to share.  

No fixed cost at this time but donations greatly appreciated to cover the space.
results.how_to_find_us: We are right at the intersection of Nason St and Summer St with the entrance on Summer.  Parking on street or in the rear.
results.name: Sunday Night Bluegrass Jam!

results.description: We are an small group of dedicated men who seek personal fulfillment in our lives and families. We follow the general outline for running weekly meetings as originates from the Mankind Project. This outline motivates us to seek meaning in our lives at the same time providing emotional and spiritual support to each other. We hope that you will join us.  -Rich Emmel
results.how_to_find_us: We meet at the back of the building off of the driveway from Mystic Valley Parkway, go to the far back door.
results.name: Personal Mastery Workgroup

results.description:
</a>

Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

<a href="https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com">https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com


(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

<a href="http://www.meetup.com/atwysspeeddating/"></a>
results.name: Speeddating Ages 30-42 - 2M/1F SPOTS LEFT

results.description:
Hi it's Josh, 

Unlike 99% of our events, this one isn't an event. 

I just learned about a new Kickstarter to support a new business that benefits solar power and the environment. 

What it is is exceptionally creative and probably my favorite Kickstarter so far. 

I hope it reaches it's goal. 

Learn more: http://www.digitaltrends.com/cool-tech/sunport-solar-power-plug-kickstarter/

Please post on the wall when you pledge. 

We anticipate volunteering with you in the near future, :)

Josh and friends

P.S. Here's the Kickstarter: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1275963200/sunport-plug-into-solar-power-no-panels-required
